sections.text:
The unique and evolving nature of the Precambrian geological environment in many ways was responsible for significant differences between Precambrian clastic sedimentary deposits and their Phanerozoic-modern equivalents. Some form of plate tectonics, with rapid microplate collisions and concomitant volcanic activity, is inferred to have led to the formation of greenstone belts. Explosive volcanism promoted common gravity-flow deposits within terrestrial greenstone settings, with braided alluvial, wave=storm-related and tidal coastline sediments also being preserved. Late Archaean accretion of greenstone terranes led to emergence of proto-cratons, where cratonic and rift sedimentary assemblages developed, and these became widespread in the Proterozoic as cratonic plates stabilised. Carbonate deposition was restricted by the paucity of stable Archaean terranes.
An Early Precambrian atmosphere characterised by greenhouse gases, including CO2, in conjunction with a faster rotation of the Earth and reduced albedo, provide a solution to the faint young Sun paradox. As emergent continental crust developed, volcanic additions of CO2 became balanced by withdrawal due to weathering and a developing Palaeoproterozoic microbial biomass. The reduction in CO2, and the photosynthetic production of O2, led to aerobic conditions probably being achieved by about 2 Ga. Oceanic growth was allied to atmospheric development, with approximately 90% of current ocean volume being reached by about 4 Ga. Warm Archaean and warm, moist Palaeoproterozoic palaeoclimates appear to have become more arid after about 2.3 Ga. The 2.4–2.3 Ga Huronian glaciation event was probably related to continental growth, supercontinent assembly and weathering-related CO2 reduction.
Despite many analogous features among both Precambrian and younger sedimentary deposits, there appear to be major differences as well. Two pertinent examples are rare unequivocal aeolian deposits prior to about 1.8 Ga and an apparent scarcity of Precambrian foreshore deposits, particularly those related to barrier island systems. The significance of these differences is hard to evaluate, particularly with the reduced palaeoenvironmental resolution because of the absence of invertebrate and plant fossils within Precambrian successions. The latter factor also poses difficulties for the discrimination of Precambrian lacustrine and shallow marine deposits. The temporal distribution of aeolian deposits probably reflects a number of possible factors, including few exposed late Archaean–Palaeoproterozoic cratonic areas, extensive pre-vegetative

Precambrian shallow marine environments may have been subjected to more uniform circulation systems than those interpreted from the Phanerozoic-modern rock record, and Precambrian shelves probably were broad with gentle seaward slopes, in contrast to the narrow, steep shelves mostly observed in present settings. Poorly confined Precambrian tidal channels formed sheet sandstones, easily confused with fluvial or offshore sand sheets. Epeiric seas were possibly more prevalent in the Precambrian, but active tectonism as proto-continents emerged and amalgamated to form early supercontinents, in conjunction with a lack of sufficient chronological data in the rock record, make it difficult to resolve the relative importance of eustatic and tectonic influences in forming epeiric embayments and seaways.
Other differences in Precambrian palaeoenvironments are more easily reconstructed. Ancient delta plain channels were probably braided, and much thicker preserved delta successions in the Precambrian are compatible with the inferred more active tectonic conditions. Pre-vegetational alluvial channel systems were almost certainly braided as well. Common fluvial quartz arenites are ascribed to differences in weathering processes, which probably changed significantly through the Precambrian, or to sediment recycling. Although Precambrian glacigenic environments were probably the least different from younger equivalents, their genesis appears to reflect a complex interplay of factors unique to the Precambrian Earth. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Clastic sedimentary rocks are known from about 4.0 Ga, and their Precambrian record thus spans approximately 85% of subsequent geological time. However, classical sedimentary models are almost exclusively based on Phanerozoic occurrences and observation of modern processes and products. Application of such models to pre-Devonian nonmarine clastic sedimentary rocks is fraught with problems due to the absence of land vegetation. As one delves farther back into the Precambrian rock record, interpretation of ancient sedimentary environments and processes becomes even more difficult, due to dynamic changes which occurred in the ocean–atmosphere, the biosphere and in the style of plate tectonics, particularly in the Archaean and Palaeoproterozoic. In addition, there is evidence in clastic sedimentary rocks for temporal changes in Earth–Moon dynamics, from Early Precambrian time until the present (e.g. Williams, 1998). The diminished palaeoenvironmental resolution of Precambrian sedimentary rocks also reflects reduced preservation of sedimentary structures, commonly caused by metamorphic overprints, limited lithological and textural variations, and an absence of diagnostic fossils and trace fossils, particularly relevant in identifying marine settings.
This paper attempts to briefly contrast the salient characteristics of Precambrian clastic depositional systems, within the continent-to-shelf environmental continuum, with their partly equivalent Phanerozoic-modern settings. Deeper marine settings, on the shelf-slope, rise and deep ocean floor are largely excluded, because their preservation potential at and beyond the tectonically active margins of Precambrian plates, micro-continents and emerging cratons is low. However, in the Archaean, submarine basins associated with arcs were comparatively common and have been preserved in a number of localities. Because of the size of the topic, organo-chemical sedimentary deposits associated with the clastic rocks are only rarely discussed.
A brief treatment of Precambrian plate tectonics, atmosphere, oceans, climates (written by Condie and Mueller) and effects of life on sedimentation (Altermann), will be followed by an overview of each major clastic depositional palaeoenvironment. The latter compare the relatively well known Phanerozoicmodern settings and processes with those inferred for the Precambrian: wave- and storm-dominated coasts, tide-dominated shallow marine systems (both written by Tirsgaard), epeiric seas (Eriksson), deltas (Catuneanu), alluvial systems (Miall; contribution from Mueller), lakes, deserts (both by Eriksson) and glacigenic deposits (Aspler and Chiarenzelli).

sections.heading: 2.1. Precambrian plate tectonics, greenstone belts and early sedimentation patterns
sections.text:
The fact that greenstones, anorogenic granites, mafic dyke swarms, and accretionary orogens all appear in the very earliest vestiges of the preserved geologic record at 4.0–3.5 Ga, strongly supports the operation of plate tectonics on the Earth by this time. It is beyond the scope of this paper to discuss this topic, and the reader is referred to recent review publications (e.g. Condie, 1994, 1997). There are data to support the existence of two late Archaean supercontinents, which underwent attenuation and fragmentation at approximately 2.5–2.0 Ga (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998). Evidence that Precambrian siliciclastic and chemical sediments accumulated at rates comparable to younger equivalent rocks suggests broadly similar crustal processes in the Precambrian (Altermann and Nelson, 1998). The first, evolving micro-continents were formed by greenstone belt accretion, and all major continents are thus cored by Archaean greenstone sequences.
A complex sedimentary history often arose from greenstone belts, observed particularly in those from the late Archaean of the Northern Hemisphere (e.g. Mueller and Donaldson, 1992; Mueller et al., 1997; Donaldson and de Kemp, 1998). For example, increased volcanic activity due to the higher Archaean heat flow would have influenced the amount of detritus shed into sedimentary basins, and would have played a major role in the control of sedimentary dispersal patterns and mass-wasting processes (Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). Arc-related sedimentary systems often suffocated by this significant introduction of pyroclastic debris, and were characterised by mass-flow processes, reflected in debris flow, hyperconcentrated flood flow, and sheetflow deposits, rather than confined, stream-dominated deposits (Mueller et al., 1994; Mueller and Corcoran, 1998).
In contrast, the sedimentology of <3.0 Ga Archaean greenstone belts from the Southern Hemisphere is suggestive of cratonic depositional settings. Plutonic clasts in conglomerate units of greenstone belts have been used by some investigators to infer the presence of sialic basement (e.g. Baragar and
McGlynn, 1976). However, plutonic detritus also can be derived from erosion of arc plutons in greenstone belts (Ojakangas, 1985; Mueller and Donaldson, 1992).

sections.heading: 2.2. The Precambrian atmosphere
sections.text:
A well known paradox associated with the increasing luminosity of the Sun with time, is that the Earth’s average surface temperature should have remained below freezing until about 2 Ga, for an atmosphere with the same composition as today (Kasting, 1987). Yet the presence of 4.0–3.8 Ga sedimentary rocks indicates the early existence of unfrozen oceans and running water. A probable solution to the faint young Sun paradox is that the early atmosphere contained a much larger quantity of greenhouse gases than it does today. For instance, CO2 levels of even a few tenths of a bar could prevent freezing temperatures at the Earth’s surface, due to an enhanced greenhouse effect. Although CO2 was undoubtedly the most important greenhouse gas during the Archaean, studies of a 3.5 Ga palaeosol in Western Australia suggest that atmospheric CO2 levels in the Archaean were at least five times lower than required to resolve the faint young Sun paradox (Rye et al., 1995) (see Section 10.3). Hence, either another greenhouse gas, such as CH4, must have been present in the Archaean atmosphere, or some other factor must have contributed to warming of the atmosphere.
Another factor that may have aided in warming the surface of the early Earth is decreased albedo. To conserve angular momentum in the Earth–Moon system, the Earth must have rotated faster in the Archaean (about 14 h=day; see also Williams, 1998), which would have decreased the fraction of global cloud cover by 20%, with a corresponding decrease in albedo (Jenkins et al., 1993). However, this effect could have been offset by increased cloud cover caused by the near-absence of land areas, at least in the early Archaean, when it is likely that the proto-continents were nearly completely submerged beneath seawater (Galer, 1991; Jenkins, 1995).
Although increased CO2 in the Archaean atmosphere would have caused greenhouse warming of the Earth’s surface, it should also have resulted in increased weathering rates (due to carbonation) and

thus, a decrease in atmospheric CO2. Studies of modern weathering show that Ca, Na, and Sr are lost rapidly during chemical weathering and that the amount of these elements lost is proportional to the degree of weathering (Wronkiewicz and Condie, 1987). Most post-Archaean shales show moderate losses of Ca, Na, and Sr from source weathering, whereas most Archaean shales show much greater losses (Condie, 1993). This suggests that the average intensity of chemical weathering was greater during the Archaean than afterwards, a conclusion consistent with a CO2-rich atmosphere in the Archaean. However, enhanced weathering rates presumably only occurred in the late Archaean, after a large volume of continental crust had stabilised above sea level.
Quartz arenites are abundant throughout most of the cratonic sedimentary record, including that of the Precambrian (e.g. Donaldson and de Kemp, 1998). Chandler (1988) examined the reasons for this, and attributed the petrological maturity to deep chemical weathering in tropical environments. Donaldson and de Kemp (1998) suggest that phanerocrystalline granitoid rocks associated with greenstone belts were a major source of first-cycle quartz arenites in the Archaean, and ascribe high Archaean weathering rates to a combination of a CO2-rich atmosphere, toxic volatiles from volcanic centres and a lack of vegetation. Corcoran et al. (1998) demonstrate that first-cycle quartz arenites were generated in highrelief areas and deposited in alluvial settings in the Archaean, due to aggressive weathering of plutonic source rocks by the CO2-rich atmosphere. Recycling of detritus through more than one cycle of basin-filling may also account for the evolution of Precambrian quartz arenites.
By 3.8 Ga, it would appear that the atmosphere was composed chiefly of CO2, N2, and perhaps CH4, with small amounts of CO, H2, H2O, and reduced sulphur gases (Kasting, 1993; Des Marais, 1994). An overall decrease in the atmospheric CO2 level during the Precambrian appears to be related to changes in the carbonate–silicate cycle, in which CO2 was removed from the atmosphere by carbonate deposition and photosynthesis, followed by burial of organic matter faster than it was resupplied by volcanism and subduction (Condie, 1997). Shallow marine carbonates deposited in cratonic basins were effectively
removed from the carbonate–silicate cycle and were a major sink for CO2. The first major carbonate platforms were those of the Chuniespoort–Ghaap Groups (Kaapvaal craton) and the Hamersley Group (Pilbara craton), deposited between about 2.68 Ga and 2.5 Ga (Simonson et al., 1993; Barton et al., 1994; Altermann and Nelson, 1998). Rapid extraction of CO2 due to deposition of marine carbonates may have contributed to sufficient atmospheric cooling to cause Palaeo- and Neoproterozoic glaciations. Weathering, as emergent land areas formed, provided an additional means of reducing atmospheric CO2.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. The growth of oxygen in the atmosphere
sections.text:
The growth of oxygen in the Earth’s atmosphere probably encompassed three stages (Kasting, 1991): (1) a reducing stage in which free oxygen occurred in neither the oceans nor the atmosphere; (2) an oxidising stage in which small amounts of oxygen were present in the atmosphere and surface ocean waters, but not in deep ocean waters; and (3) an aerobic stage in which free oxygen pervaded the entire ocean–atmosphere system.
During the first stage, marine cyanobacteria must have produced O2 by photosynthesis, and for relatively large volumes of BIF to form, as observed in Archaean greenstone belt successions, this oxygen must have combined rapidly with Fe2C and been deposited. Stage one would have lasted until the amount of O2 produced by photosynthesis followed by organic carbon burial was enough to overwhelm the input of volcanic gases.
The change from first to second stage probably occurred during the Palaeoproterozoic, a transition period marked by the appearance of redbeds at 2.3 Ga, an increase in the abundance of evaporitic sulphates, a broad maximum in the deposition rate of BIF at 2.5 Ga, and the end of major detrital uraninite–pyrite deposition (Condie, 1997). Evidence that the lower atmosphere and surface ocean waters during this second stage were weakly oxidising, while deep marine waters were reducing, is provided by the simultaneous deposition of oxidised surface sediments (redbeds, evaporites), and BIF in a non-oxidising palaeoenvironment. However, Eriksson and Cheney (1992) have drawn attention to the diagenetic overprint on 2.3–2.1 Ga redbeds, emphasising the complexities involved in interpreting
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 9
Precambrian atmospheric conditions, during sedimentation, from such rocks.
The change from the second to third stage probably occurred at about 2.0 Ga, as oxygen rapidly entered the atmosphere (Holland, 1994). This transition is inferred from the near disappearance of BIF from the geologic record and by the appearance of eukaryotic microorganisms. Ohmoto (1996) has suggested that the continental biomass may have been greater in the Palaeoproterozoic than generally assumed, and that evolution of atmospheric oxygen may have begun prior to 2.2 Ga. The onset of stage three was marked by the depletion of Fe2C in the oceans, such that photosynthetic O2 levels increased and the oceans became oxidising. Further increases resulted in the liberation of O2 into the atmosphere, allowing development of an effective ozone screen, which was probably responsible for the rapid diversification and proliferation of microorganisms observed in Mesoproterozoic successions. By 540 Ma, atmospheric O2 must have risen to at least 10% PAL, to permit the appearance of carbonate shell-forming organisms (Cloud, 1968).

sections.heading: 2.3. Precambrian oceans
sections.text:
The geological history of oceans and the concentration of volatile elements in seawater was controlled, in part, by atmospheric evolution (Holland et al., 1986). Most palaeoclimatologists agree that the oceans formed early in Earth history, by condensation of atmospheric water. It is likely that the growth rate of the oceans paralleled that of the atmosphere, perhaps with a slight delay reflecting the time necessary for a steam atmosphere to cool and condense. A large fraction of the oceans probably formed during the late stages of planetary accretion, such that by 4.0 Ga, most of the current volume of seawater (>90%) was in place on the Earth’s surface (Condie, 1997).
Because of the inferred relatively high CO2 content of the early atmosphere, the first seawater to condense must have had a low pH (<7), due to dissolved CO2 and other acidic components such as H2S and HCl. However, this situation was probably short-lived, in that submarine volcanic eruptions and recycling of seawater through ocean ridges would have introduced large amounts of Na, Ca, and Fe.
A pH between 8 and 9 and a neutral or negative Eh were thus probably attained rapidly in the early oceans, and would have been maintained thereafter by silicate–seawater buffering reactions and recycling at ocean ridges (Condie, 1997).
Although it is commonly assumed that the composition of seawater has not changed appreciably with time, some observational and theoretical data challenge this assumption. For instance, some Archaean marine carbonates contain giant botryoids of aragonite, and Mg-calcite beds up to several metres thick that extend for many kilometres (Grotzinger and Kasting, 1993). By comparison, Palaeoproterozoic carbonates have much less spectacular occurrences of these minerals, although cement crusts in tidal flat deposits are common. In contrast, these features are rare in younger marine carbonates and, in the case of the cements, show a progressive decline in abundance with age.
Another difference between Precambrian and Phanerozoic sediments is the sequence of evaporite deposition. In Palaeoproterozoic sediments, halite was commonly deposited immediately on top of carbonate, without intervening sulphates. Although minor occurrences of evaporitic gypsum are reported in the Archaean (Buick and Dunlop, 1990), they appear to reflect the influence of local source rocks on seawater composition. The first extensive sulphates were deposited in the MacArthur basin, Australia, at 1.7–1.6 Ga. The paucity of gypsum evaporites prior to 1.7 Ga may reflect low concentrations of sulphate in seawater before this time; alternatively, the bicarbonate : Ca ratio may have been sufficiently high that during progressive seawater evaporation, Ca was exhausted by carbonate precipitation before the gypsum stability field was reached (Grotzinger and Kasting, 1993).

sections.heading: 2.4. Precambrian climates
sections.text:
Average surface temperatures and precipitation regimes during the Precambrian can be characterised by using palaeoclimatic indicators and models of atmospheric evolution. Greenhouse warming of the early atmosphere may have resulted in average surface temperatures much greater than at present. Unfortunately, few climatic indicators are preserved in Archaean supracrustal successions, thus mak-

ing broad generalisations questionable. Early Archaean evaporites and stromatolitic carbonates, however, favour generally warm climates, and Archaean fluvial sandstones and conglomerates are indicative of significant rainfall (e.g. Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). As previously discussed, although not necessitating high Archaean temperatures, the low concentrations of Ca, Na, and Sr in Archaean shales are consistent with such conditions.
The relative abundance of shallow marine carbonates and the preservation of lateritic palaeosols in the Proterozoic suggest a continuation of warm, moist climates after the end of the Archaean. The increasing proportion of evaporites and redbeds after 2.3 Ga appears to record the increasing importance of semiarid to arid climatic regimes. Colder climates, recorded by widespread glacial deposits, alternated with warm and moist climates, reflected by marine carbonates, in the Neoproterozoic (see Section 10).
Although data indicate that Archaean and Palaeoproterozoic climates were warmer than at present, at least two glaciations must be accommodated: one at approximately 3.0 Ga (Pongola Supergroup, South Africa) and one at 2.4–2.3 Ga (Huronian glaciations in Laurentia–Baltica) (Section 10). The absence of significant amounts of volcanic rock beneath tillites of both these ages does not support the injection of volcanic dust into the atmosphere (thereby reducing sunlight) as a cause of either glaciation. The 3.0 Ga glaciation is recorded only in the eastern part of the Kaapvaal craton in South Africa, and may have been caused by local conditions (Von Brunn and Gold, 1993).
However, for the Palaeoproterozoic glaciation, a widespread drawdown mechanism for atmospheric CO2 appears necessary (Young, 1991). One possibility is that increasing numbers of photosynthetic microorganisms extracted CO2 from the atmosphere faster than it could be returned by the carbonate– silicate cycle, thus reducing the greenhouse effect. Glaciation may have ended as a result of the concomitant decline of stromatolites due to the cooling. However, large amounts of marine carbonates produced during the CO2 withdrawal do not generally occur beneath Early Precambrian tillites. Another possibility that has not been fully evaluated, is the effect that rapid continental growth in the late Archaean (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998) may have
had on the CO2 content of the atmosphere. Perhaps rapid chemical weathering of the newly formed cratons reduced CO2 levels in the atmosphere and led to cooling and glaciation. Both Palaeo- and Neoproterozoic glaciations appear to have occurred at low latitudes, and this palaeoclimatic paradox is even more puzzling (Williams, 1998) (Section 10).

sections.heading: 2.5. The impact of Precambrian life on sedimentation
sections.text:
The scientific literature on the increasing impact of the growing biosphere on Precambrian sedimentation patterns is vast, and the reader is referred to reviews by Schopf (1983, 1992), De Duve (1991), Schopf and Klein (1992), Bengtson (1994) and Knoll (1996). The first visible impact of life on sedimentation was the appearance of bio-sediments, represented by stromatolites. Sedimentation rates calculated for Archaean stromatolitic carbonate successions suggest that growth rates for shallow water and peritidal stromatolites were comparable to those observed in modern stromatolitic tidal flats and reefs (Altermann and Nelson, 1998). The search for a stratigraphic subdivision of the Archaean and Proterozoic aeons in the absence of body fossils promoted many attempts to use stromatolites for this purpose, but without significant success.
The usefulness of stromatolites as universal indicators of tidal facies is also disputable. Although recent stromatolites are mainly restricted to the peritidal environment, sedimentary facies associations imply that some Precambrian stromatolites grew even in deep subtidal regimes, between the fair weather and the storm wave base (ca. 100 m depth). This is surprising considering the lower luminosity of the Early Precambrian Sun, and the presumed higher suspension load of the water in the absence of filtering organisms and of biomineralisation. Some investigators propose that certain microbial mats might have been non-photosynthesising and could grow in depths below the photic zone (Simonson et al., 1993). Perhaps this was possible, with the absence of oxygen which is toxic to anaerobic microbes, but no unequivocal examples of such non-photosynthesising mats have yet been documented in Precambrian strata.
Stromatolites and microbial communities probably also had an effect on clastic sedimentation
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 11
systems (Schieber, 1998). High siliciclastic influx usually prevents microbial growth on a sediment surface, but microbial communities might also have existed below the sediment–water interface. Probable stromatolitic structures are known from the Proterozoic of the Great Slave Province, where conical columns seem to be embedded in turbidites (Hoffman, 1974). Schieber (1998) suggests that microbial mats colonised shallow water and episodically emergent muddy and sandy sediment surfaces in the Mesoproterozoic Belt Supergroup, Montana. The Belt basin was probably epeiric, but may also have been lacustrine (Schieber, 1998). It is difficult to assess when the microbial mats entered non-marine realms, because it is generally impossible to distinguish Archaean marine and non-marine environments. Microbial communities colonised supratidal flats (Altermann and Herbig, 1991) and from there might also have inhabited moist soils on land. The spread of microbial life into isolated basins or lakes was probably induced by winds eroding desiccated stromatolitic mats. Fragments of microbial mats are recognisable in intraclasts by the plastic deformation of the desiccation rubble. Pflüger and Gresse (1996) proposed the term ‘microbial sand chips’ for intraclasts consolidated by microbial activity. Such highly deformed desiccated sand chips, with raindrop imprints, are known for example from non-marine sediments in the 2.7 Ga Ventersdorp Supergroup (Van der Westhuizen et al., 1989). Their cohesiveness may have been strengthened by microbial activity. Microscopic studies, however, do not reveal any organic remnants in these chips and carbon isotopic studies have not yet been performed on these rocks. Cohesive behaviour of clastic sediment laminae during soft-sediment deformation may be one of a number of possible diagnostic features of microbial colonisation of clastic sediment surfaces (Schieber, 1998).
A carbon-rich palaeosol below the 2.64 Ga Black Reef Quartzite Formation (Transvaal Supergroup, South Africa) was described by Martini (1994), who concluded that the carbon was derived from microbial mats, which thrived in a continental palaeoenvironment during formation of the palaeosol. Some geochemical evidence for widespread microbial communities in late Archaean and Palaeoproterozoic palaeosols has been presented by Ohmoto (1996), who has advocated the importance of organic acids
as agents for leaching ferric oxides in Precambrian weathering profiles. Possible microbial mats on soils would give only weak protection against erosion in continental realms. The siliciclastic influx into Precambrian sedimentary basins must therefore have been strong and the sedimentation rates rather high. Under such conditions, stromatolites could not have spread significantly until tectonism and erosion stabilised to allow for the development of stable basins at the end of the late Archaean (Altermann and Nelson, 1998).

sections.heading: 3. Wave- and storm-dominated shallow marine depositional systems
3.1. Introduction
sections.text:
Shallow marine settings, regardless of age or predominant hydrodynamic regime, consist of a continuum of depositional environments, ranging from the beach or foreshore, through the shoreface and out to the inner and outer shelf. The foreshore is defined here as that part of the shelf dominated by the swash and backwash of breaking waves, whereas the shoreface is the zone between sea level and normal wave base. The inner shelf is defined as the zone between normal wave base and storm wave base, and the outer shelf as the zone lying below storm wave base.
Although the distinction between Precambrian shallow marine and continental deposits may be of serious concern (Dott et al., 1986; Mueller and Dimroth, 1987; Sønderholm and Jepsen, 1991; Lindsey and Gaylord, 1992; Eriksson et al., 1993, 1995; McCormick and Grotzinger, 1993; Bose and Chakraborty, 1994; Donaldson and de Kemp, 1998; Schieber, 1998), successions ascribed to wave- and storm-dominated shallow marine deposition appear to be relatively common in the Precambrian geological record. They typically comprise either metre-thick upward-coarsening units, commonly interpreted as parasequences (Eriksson and Simpson, 1990; Jackson et al., 1990; Tirsgaard, 1996), or they form successions of homogeneous sandstone hundreds to thousands of metres thick, generally showing an apparent lack of cyclic or sequential development (Cant and Hein, 1986; Chandler, 1988). These sequences appear to contain a remarkably uniform development of sedimentary structures and a noticeable lack of ver-
12 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
tical trends (e.g. Cant and Hein, 1986; Dott et al., 1986; Strachan, 1986; Bose and Chakraborty, 1994; Tirsgaard and Sønderholm, 1997). Interpretations of Precambrian shallow marine environments are therefore strongly dependent on facies combinations and successions, and palaeoenvironmental interpretations rely heavily on modern analogues.

sections.heading: 3.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
3.2.1. Outer and inner shelf
sections.text:
Precambrian outer and inner shelf deposits both appear to be characterised by the same sedimentological and lithological features as Phanerozoicmodern shelf deposits (e.g. Levell, 1980; Eriksson et al., 1981; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Harris and Eriksson, 1990; Jackson et al., 1990; Ghosh, 1991; Sønderholm and Jepsen, 1991; Dirks and Norman, 1992; Lindsey and Gaylord, 1992; Tirsgaard and
Sønderholm, 1997). However, with few exceptions (e.g. Schieber, 1989; Chakraborty and Bose, 1992), studies of Precambrian shelf deposits focus on nearshore sandstones (Fig. 1), whereas outer shelf deposits, comprising massive or laminated mudstones, with subordinate, storm-deposited graded siltstone and very fine-grained sandstone beds, are described and interpreted only briefly.
Comparisons between Phanerozoic and Precambrian outer and, to some extent, inner shelf deposits are thus based on limited evidence, and there are indications that our current understanding of the Precambrian shelf environment may be an over-simplification (e.g. Chakraborty and Bose, 1992). Tirsgaard and Sønderholm (1997) describe inferred outer shelf successions from the Lyell Land Group, Greenland, which are many tens of metres thick, and which consist almost exclusively of 0.5–2.0 cm thick, silty graded beds (Fig. 2). Such homogeneous deposits, virtually lacking pelagic mudstones, suggest a more
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 13
regular and uniform emplacement of storm deposits than appears to be characteristic of Phanerozoicmodern outer shelf deposits.
This could have been a response to storms which occurred regularly and frequently in the Precambrian, or it could reflect a persistent and uniform sediment distribution system on the shelf. An alternative explanation is a wide and very low-angle Precambrian shelf, with a delicate balance between sediment input, sediment dispersal and subsidence. These same factors have also been proposed to explain the uniform development of thick Precambrian and early Palaeozoic shallow marine and continental orthoquartzite successions around the world (Cant and Hein, 1986; Dott et al., 1986; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1989). The development of wide,
low-angle shelf settings in the Precambrian would have been encouraged by the high denudation rate of vegetation-free landscapes (Els, 1998).
The general lack of interest in Precambrian muddy shelf deposits is puzzling, because the absence of biogenic activity, particularly bioturbation, results in considerably better preservation of sedimentary structures than is seen in younger deposits. A potential thus exists for a more detailed understanding of the depositional dynamics of the Phanerozoic-modern outer (and inner) shelf environment, from Precambrian examples such as the Mesoproterozoic Newland Formation, Belt basin, Montana (Schieber, 1989), or the Proterozoic Kaimur Formation, India (Chakraborty and Bose, 1992).
Due to the absence of fossils and biogenic activity, Precambrian inner shelf sediments, comprising interbedded storm-deposited sandstone beds and fair weather mudstones, can be especially difficult to distinguish from fluvial overbank facies. This may be a particularly vexing problem where the typical upward-shallowing trend of marine successions is absent or only poorly developed. In these cases, hummocky cross-stratification (HCS) is commonly the only sedimentary structure which positively denotes a marine (or lacustrine) environment (Fig. 1), in contrast to other structures in the sandstone beds, such as parallel lamination, ripples and soft-sediment deformation structures.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Shoreface
sections.text:
Shoreface deposits are subject to persistent wave action and contain a variety of bedforms. Precambrian shoreface deposits are characterised by highly mature, well sorted sandstones, as are younger shoreface sediments (Walker and Plint, 1992), with virtually no mudstone, although pebbles and pebble lags may occur (e.g. Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Harris and Eriksson, 1990). Dominant sedimentary structures are HCS, swaley cross-stratification, parallel lamination, and trough and planar cross-bedding, which appear to form similar successions to those seen in Phanerozoic shoreface deposits (e.g. Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Bose et al., 1988; Jackson et al., 1990; Lindsey and Gaylord, 1992; Tirsgaard and Sønderholm, 1997).
The hummocky and swaley cross-stratification and parallel lamination are typical of storm-domi-
14 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
nated coasts (Snedden and Nummedal, 1990; Walker and Plint, 1992), whereas in most interpretations, cross-beds are simply considered to represent two- or three-dimensional dunes, which migrated on the Precambrian shoreface in response to fair weather longshore, onshore, or offshore currents. In many cases these bedforms show a wide dispersion of migration directions. Oscillatory and combined-flow ripples are similarly characteristic of the shoreface zone. Bioturbation is relatively uncommon in Phanerozoic-modern shoreface settings, these deposits being more comparable to their Precambrian equivalents than outer shelf mudrocks.
Within late Archaean greenstone belts, such as the 2.7 Ga Abitibi belt in Canada, there was often a rapid transition from alluvial deposits derived from emergent dissected island arcs, into high-gradient and high-energy shoreface palaeoenvironments, where wave and storm activity predominated over apparently negligible tidal action (Mueller and Donaldson, 1992). In the late Archaean Keskarrah Formation, Slave Province, Canada, there was an intimate association of fan-deltas with both wave and tidally influenced shallow marine systems (Corcoran et al., 1998). More distinct analyses of wave- and stormdominated shoreface dynamics, or detailed documentations of depositional architecture are rare, and come mostly from the Precambrian of India (e.g. Bose et al., 1988; Chakraborty and Bose, 1990).
Our understanding of Precambrian shoreface dynamics and depositional architecture is therefore limited. However, several authors describe inferred Precambrian shoreface deposits which comprise successions of homogeneous sandstone, generally several metres to hundreds of metres in thickness, which consist almost exclusively of 10–30 cm thick planar and trough cross-beds (e.g. Eriksson, 1977; Levell, 1980; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Strachan, 1986; Mueller and Dimroth, 1987; Harris and Eriksson, 1990; Jackson et al., 1990; Ghosh, 1991; Tirsgaard and Sønderholm, 1997). The development of such successions, which commonly are at least an order of magnitude thicker than typical Phanerozoic shoreface deposits (e.g. Elliott, 1986), and yet appear to contain a more restricted variety of sedimentary structures, has never been satisfactorily explained. More uniform, and possibly more permanent circulation systems than those observed on modern
shelves, combined with a delicate balance between subsidence and sediment influx, have been offered as possible explanations (e.g. Cant and Hein, 1986; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1989).

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Foreshore
sections.text:
As is the case for Phanerozoic wave- and storm-dominated foreshore deposits, the Precambrian equivalents are poorly preserved in the geological record, and descriptions of inferred deposits are rare. Foreshore deposits reflect high-energy shoaling wave conditions, and mostly consist of well-sorted sandstones characterised by parallel lamination, locally graded, and in some places having a low-angle seaward dip (Clifton, 1969); cross-bedding and wave ripples generally are subordinate structures, and bioturbation is sparse in Phanerozoic-modern examples. Vos and Eriksson (1977), Eriksson (1979), Bose et al. (1988) and Bose and Chakraborty (1994) describe Precambrian foreshore deposits dominated by plane bedding with internal truncation surfaces, some small-scale cross-beds and cross-lamination, and desiccation cracks, suggesting that these are similar to their Phanerozoic counterparts.
Where wave-dominated barrier islands form, washover fans and channels typically develop in response to major storms and may form a significant part of Phanerozoic-modern foreshore deposits (Reinson, 1992). Lagoons developed behind the barriers typically accumulate mud, although significant proportions of the lagoon-fill may consist of washover fan and channel sands (Elliott, 1986). Precambrian washover fan deposits have only been described by Eriksson (1979), from an Archaean microtidal coastline identified in the Barberton greenstone belt, South Africa, where they formed successions up to 8 m thick. However, the apparent absence of sediments from barrier island settings in the Precambrian is most likely a reflection of the difficulties in identifying them in mature quartz arenite deposits which invariably constitute the preserved Precambrian foreshore successions.

sections.heading: 3.3. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
Successions interpreted as products of Precambrian wave- and storm-dominated shallow marine depositional systems are characterised by very uniform
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 15
suites of sedimentary structures, and lack vertical trends within the thick homogeneous orthoquartzitic sandstones often preserved from such environments. Wide and low-angle shelves, or a more persistent and uniform sediment dispersal pattern are thus generally invoked for the Precambrian. There are also indications that Precambrian outer shelf storms may have been more regular than in younger settings. Descriptions of Precambrian barrier island, washover fan and lagoon deposits are rare in the literature. More uniform or permanent circulation systems than those interpreted from the Phanerozoic and observed today, may thus be inferred for Precambrian highenergy shallow marine palaeoenvironments. In addition, sediment influx and subsidence were probably more finely balanced than in younger settings.

sections.heading: 4.1. Introduction
sections.text:
Modern tide-dominated shallow marine environments comprise a continuum from microtidal barrier island systems with quiescent muddy lagoons, through mesotidal barrier island systems with well developed tidal flats and channels, to open-ended macrotidal estuaries with extensive tidal flats, tidal channels and large tidal sandwaves or tidal ridges (Hayes, 1979; Dalrymple, 1992; Reinson, 1992). Interpreting preserved tidal shallow marine deposits is complicated by the fact that many structures traditionally assigned to a tidal environment, such as herringbone cross-stratification, recurrent thickening and thinning of foresets, and abundant reactivation surfaces, may also occur in fluvial settings (Alam et al., 1985; Tirsgaard, 1993). Thus, some deposits considered to be of tidal origin may in fact consist of a complex interbedding of tidal and continental deposits, particularly in the effectively non-fossiliferous Precambrian (e.g. Eriksson et al., 1995).
Precambrian shallow marine deposits of tidal origin commonly occur in mature well-sorted sandstone successions, many tens to several hundred metres thick, and appear to form a significant part of the Precambrian sedimentary record (e.g. Anderton, 1976; Eriksson, 1977, 1979; Johnson, 1977; Vos and Eriksson, 1977; Levell, 1980; Eriksson et al.,
1981, 1995; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Harris and Eriksson, 1990; Jackson et al., 1990; Ghosh, 1991; Simpson and Eriksson, 1991; Dirks and Norman, 1992; Lindsey and Gaylord, 1992; Deynoux et al., 1993; Tirsgaard, 1993; ; Tirsgaard and Sønderholm, 1997). Sedimentary structures in these Precambrian sandstones are limited, mostly comprising apparent herringbone cross-stratification or bundled foresets (Fig. 3) (e.g. Anderton, 1976; Levell, 1980; Strachan, 1986; Dirks and Norman, 1992), whereas the major part of such successions lacks features diagnostic of the depositional environment.

sections.heading: 4.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
4.2.1. Shoreface and inner shelf; tidal sandwaves and ridges
sections.text:
Sandwave deposits, formed on intertidal or subtidal parts of the shoreface or on the inner shelf, compose most inferred Precambrian tidal sediments described in the literature (e.g. Anderton, 1976; Johnson, 1977; Levell, 1980; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Chakraborty and Bose, 1990; Harris and Eriksson, 1990; Jackson et al., 1990; Simpson and Eriksson, 1991; Dirks and Norman, 1992; Bose and Chakraborty, 1994). They are mostly identified on the basis of a predominance of largescale planar cross-beds up to several metres thick, commonly combined in compound sets, with subordinate large-scale trough cross-bedding and ripple lamination. Extensive cross-cutting erosion surfaces may be present (Simpson and Eriksson, 1991). Cross-beds show indications of current reversals, mainly in the form of herringbone cross-stratification, bundled foresets and reactivation surfaces (Fig. 3) (Chakraborty and Bose, 1990; Simpson and Eriksson, 1991; Mueller and Donaldson, 1994; Corcoran et al., 1995, 1998).
The Precambrian sandwave deposits appear to have an internal architecture similar to modern (e.g. Allen, 1980; Johnson and Baldwin, 1986) counterparts. The internal architecture of present-day tidal sand ridges, at least an order of magnitude larger than sandwaves, is poorly understood, but seismic data indicate that many tidal ridges contain a series of large-scale, gently inclined surfaces, along which dunes migrated under the influence of tidal currents
16 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
(Dalrymple, 1992). Examples of inferred Precambrian tidal sand ridges are rare. Johnson (1977) described sandstone bodies more than 6 m thick, which he inferred to be tidal sand ridges, similar to modern examples in the North Sea. Internally, they display trough cross-beds separated by low-angle planar surfaces which formed by dunes migrating along the axes of the ridges, presumably in response to storm and tidal currents. The sandstone bodies were dissected by channels which appear to have been swept by reversing tidal currents, and to have been filled by two- and three-dimensional dunes.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Barrier beach, tidal inlets and tidal deltas
sections.text:
Barrier beach deposits consist of a shoreface, the intertidal foreshore, and supratidal washover fans and channels. Tidal inlets and deltas form an integral part of barrier island complexes and may comprise a substantial part of the upper shoreface or foreshore deposits (Elliott, 1986; Reinson, 1992). Flood-tidal deltas are best developed along wavedominated coasts; ebb-tidal deltas generally develop more complex deposits, and they are best preserved along tide-dominated coasts (Boothroyd, 1985; Elliott, 1986; Reinson, 1992).
Examples of Precambrian tidally induced shoreface deposits are common in the literature, but there is a noticeable lack of examples of inferred barrier island and associated tidal inlet and tidal delta deposits. With few exceptions (e.g. Eriksson, 1979; Williams, 1998), tidally influenced Precambrian shelves are typically depicted as lacking barrier islands and associated tidal deltas and inlets (e.g. Anderton, 1976; Eriksson, 1977; Vos and Eriksson, 1977; Levell, 1980; Soegaard and Eriksson, 1985; Dott et al., 1986; Harris and Eriksson, 1990; Jackson et al., 1990; Ghosh, 1991; Lindsey and Gaylord, 1992; Bose and Chakraborty, 1994; Eriksson et al., 1995). However, tidal rhythmites, best preserved in ebb-tidal delta settings, have enabled palaeogeophysical analysis to be made of the Earth–Moon system in the Neoproterozoic (Williams, 1998).
Two Archaean examples of inferred tidal inlet deposits have been described by Eriksson (1979) and Eriksson et al. (1981), from the Barberton greenstone belt and Witwatersrand basin, Kaapvaal craton. These deposits comprise upward-fining units with the base marked by a conglomeratic lag, which is overlain by sandstones exhibiting planar cross-beds and interlayered planar bedding. The
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 17
supposed deeper parts of the inlet deposits are characterised by unidirectional foreset dips, with bidirectional dips developed in the upper parts. Shale drapes along foresets are common. The succession of sedimentary structures strongly resembles modern tidal inlet deposits described by Kumar and Sanders (1974) and Elliott (1986).
Although equally uncommon, Precambrian floodtidal delta deposits have likewise been described by Eriksson (1979). These were found to be intercalated with tidal flat sediments and consist of large- and medium-scale planar and trough cross-bedded sandstones. Flood-oriented cross-beds predominate, but bimodal and bipolar palaeocurrent trends occur locally, presumably reflecting areas where ebb currents were confined. These flood-tidal delta sediments bear a close resemblance to modern counterparts (e.g. Boersma and Terwindt, 1981; Boothroyd, 1985).

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Lagoons, tidal flats and channels
sections.text:
Phanerozoic-modern lagoonal deposits generally consist of a complex interbedding of mudstones, siltstones and sandstones, with the coarser sediments reflecting washover fans or flood-tidal deltas; the finergrained deposits include those of the subtidal lagoon and the adjacent subtidal to intertidal flats (Reinson, 1992). Vegetation and bioturbation, commonly important in these younger settings, obviously have no relevance in Precambrian deposits. The muddy subtidal back-barrier deposits which characterise many modern-day lagoons (Elliott, 1986) have not been reported from Precambrian settings. Precambrian lagoonal deposits described in the literature typically consist of subtidal and intertidal flat sediments and tidal channel sediments (Vos and Eriksson, 1977; Deynoux et al., 1993; Tirsgaard, 1993; Eriksson et al., 1995), or, more rarely, of inferred flood-tidal and washover fan deposits (Eriksson, 1979).
Precambrian tidal flat deposits strongly resemble their younger counterparts, and typically consist of flaser, wavy and lenticular bedded heterolites (thinly interbedded sandstones and mudstones), commonly with desiccation features (Vos and Eriksson, 1977; Eriksson, 1979; Tirsgaard, 1993). Modern tidal flats are drained by a network of meandering tidal creeks and the channel-fill deposits comprise interbedded sand and mud, which may contain tidal rhythmites (Dalrymple et al., 1991). Meandering tidal channels
appear to have been notably absent on Precambrian tidal flats. Instead, wide, sandy and poorly confined tidal channels, developing several metre-thick sand sheets (Fig. 4), have been described (Tirsgaard, 1993; Eriksson et al., 1995). Internally, these sand sheets are dominated by parallel lamination, largescale cross-beds showing bundled foresets, bipolar foreset dip directions, numerous reactivation surfaces and flood and ebb caps. These tidal channel sand sheets may be difficult to distinguish from both fluvial sand sheets (Tirsgaard, 1993; Eriksson et al., 1995; Els, 1998) and offshore tidal deposits, which could explain the limited examples of Precambrian back-barrier tidal channels in the geological literature.

sections.heading: 4.3. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
A lack of depositional trends and the development of homogeneous successions up to a hundred metres thick or more, appear to be the most notable differences from Phanerozoic-modern tidal shelf deposits. Nevertheless, many of these successions have been interpreted on the basis of a comparison with the present-day North Sea (e.g. Anderton, 1976; Johnson, 1977; Levell, 1980). Considering that many Precambrian tidal deposits possibly formed on much wider and shallower shelves than the relatively narrow modern shelves, it seems likely that our current concepts of Precambrian tidal shelf dynamics are over-simplified. Precambrian epeiric seas further complicate interpretations; the differentiation of such settings from those discussed here may not be possible (Section 5).
Inherent differences in the depositional dynamics and processes of Phanerozoic-modern and Precambrian shelves may possibly also explain the apparent lack of sediments ascribed to barrier islands and associated tidal deltas and inlets in Precambrian barrier beach deposits. An alternative explanation could be low palaeoenvironmental resolution of the near-coastal Precambrian tidal settings, because of the commonly high maturity of the preserved sandstones.
Tirsgaard (1993) suggested that the difference in channel morphology of creeks draining Precambrian tidal flats, compared to Phanerozoic-modern equivalents, reflects a combination of low concentrations
18 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
of mud on the flats and an absence of stabilising vegetation, and that Precambrian tidal channel-fills may therefore be characterised by their sand sheet geometries.

sections.heading: 5.1. Introduction
sections.text:
Discrimination between ancient shelf sea deposits (Sections 3 and 4) and those of pre-existing epeiric seas, which reflect flooding of cratonic areas due to raised sea level (Reading, 1978), is problematic (Friedman et al., 1992). Because true epeiric seas on the scale of the geologic past are absent today, comparisons with modern continental margins is questionable (Reading, 1978; Hallam, 1981; Friedman et al., 1992). Epeiric seaways appear to have been characterised by shelf-like environments, shelfbreaks, often with deeper distal regions, and strongly directional currents, in contrast to the shallower and smaller epeiric embayments, which lacked true shelfbreaks and ocean-type currents. Phanerozoic seaways more closely resembled modern open ocean shelves (Brenner, 1980) and were essentially shallow oceans rather than epeiric seas (sensu stricto) like the
smaller embayments. Presumably, these differences applied equally in the Precambrian, although the effect of a much reduced biological diversity at that time is difficult to assess.

sections.heading: 5.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and Phanerozoic settings
sections.text:
The classic Shaw (1964) and Irwin (1965) epeiric sea model envisaged three belts: (1) a wide, lowenergy, open sea ‘X zone’ below wave base; (2) a narrow and high-energy wave and tidally influenced ‘Y zone’; and (3) a shallow landward ‘Z zone’, with low-energy conditions, poor circulation, minimal tides, and minor storm-generated local wave action (Fig. 5). Despite the model being supported partly by modern processes, it must be seriously qualified (e.g. Schopf, 1980).
Although maximum water depths of about 200 m were assumed in the model, epeiric seas are now thought to have been shallower than modern continental shelves; long-period swells would thus have been dissipated at epeiric sea margins (e.g. Friedman et al., 1992). Estimation of bathymetry in ancient epeiric seas is difficult. Widespread carbonate deposits in inferred Phanerozoic examples point to
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 19
depths of 30 m or less, but phosphate nodules in black shales in other cases indicate anoxic seafloor conditions and depths possibly in excess of 100 m (Friedman et al., 1992). Variable oceanographic conditions probably applied to epeiric seas with different bathymetric characteristics. In water depths up to 30 m, maximum possible wavelengths of waves would have been 60 m, with periods of 6–10 s, giving waves comparable to modern storm wind-induced ocean waves (King, 1959; Friedman and Sanders, 1978; Friedman et al., 1992).
Another qualification of the Shaw–Irwin model applies to tidal energy. Extensive peritidal flat deposits have been identified along the shoaling portions of inferred Phanerozoic epeiric sea basins (e.g. Swett et al., 1971; Banks, 1973; Reading, 1978; Pratt and James, 1986; Friedman et al., 1992). Tidal height may, in fact, increase as open ocean tides approach a wide, shallow water platform (Klein, 1982; Pratt and James, 1986). Elongate, funnel-like shapes of epeiric seaways probably also promoted interaction of tidal and storm processes (Galloway and Hobday, 1983). Hypersaline conditions probably occurred locally in epeiric seas (Friedman et al., 1992), with the converse possibility of widespread brackish water offshore from humid coastline areas (Hallam, 1981).
Sedimentary processes responsible for forming sandwaves and ridges in Phanerozoic seaways appear to have been analogous to those observed on present-day continental shelves (Brenner and Davies, 1974; Spearing, 1976; Brenner, 1978, 1979; Klein and Ryder, 1978; Bouma et al., 1982) (Section 4).
Phanerozoic seaways were thus most likely relatively analogous to modern shelf seas, with unidirectional ocean-type currents, storm wave activity, micro- to mesotidal conditions and salinity gradients. Their scale of preserved outcrop, and better preservation compared to Precambrian counterparts, makes their identification relatively easy, as for example with the classic Mesozoic epeiric seaway deposits in North America (e.g. Brenner, 1978; Bouma et al., 1982; Swift and Rice, 1984). The discrimination of Precambrian epeiric seaways from preserved shelf seas would depend to a large degree on whether the scale of transgression could be established. Identification of the small epeiric embayments, both in the Phanerozoic and Precambrian, is difficult, such deposits being easily confused with sediments from preserved shelf seas.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Archaean Witwatersrand–Pongola epeiric sea, Kaapvaal craton
sections.text:
Inferred Precambrian epeiric sea successions are not common in the geological literature. The Archaean Witwatersrand and coeval Pongola Supergroups in South Africa may be an example of such deposits. The greater Witwatersrand basin is thought to have encompassed the upper, Mozaan Group of the Pongola succession, and to have formed between about 3074 and 2714 Ma (Beukes and Cairncross, 1991; Robb and Meyer, 1995). Preserved outcrops suggest that inundation of the Kaapvaal proto-cratonic terrane extended for at least 400 km inland of the inferred southern limit of the micro-continent, and for a minimum of 600 km along the develop-
20 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
ing craton’s margin (Fig. 6). Maximum transgression appears to have characterised the lower West Rand (Group) epeiric sea sedimentation, with the upper Central Rand (Group) deposits being related to a much reduced, fluvial–shallow marine remnant Witwatersrand basin (Stanistreet and McCarthy, 1991). The Witwatersrand–Pongola basin may have been either a foreland basin, analogous to the Mesozoic seaway of North America (Armstrong, 1968), or might reflect thermal subsidence following extension related to volcanism of the Dominion and Nsuze Groups (underlie, respectively, the West Rand and Mozaan Groups), similar to the model inferred for the North Sea (Stanistreet and McCarthy, 1991).
Storm- and tide-dominated subtidal sand sheets within an extensive West Rand Group–Mozaan
Group epeiric sea setting were discussed by Stanistreet and McCarthy (1991); Eriksson et al. (1981) proposed shoreline, shoreface and subtidal environments, with meso- to macrotidal ranges for the lower parts of the West Rand Group. These inferred tidedominated sand bodies appear to be analogous to those in the modern North Sea (Stanistreet and McCarthy, 1991). Els (1998) discusses interaction of braided fluvial and tidal channels within the Central Rand Group auriferous palaeoplacers. In contrast, in the Mozaan Group, Pongola Supergroup, Beukes and Cairncross (1991) observed little evidence of tidal processes. They defined a current-dominated shelf sand facies laid down above normal wave base, a storm-dominated shelf sand facies with predominant hummocky cross-bedding, and a shelf mud facies
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 21
which might reflect shallow inner shelf to outer shelf depths. These facies are also analogous to Phanerozoic-modern and Precambrian inner shelf deposits (Section 3.2.1). All of the inferred Mozaan shelf-like sediments are interbedded with fluvial braidplain sandstones (Beukes and Cairncross, 1991), and the entire succession may thus represent relatively shallow shelf conditions close to the shoreline. Beukes (1996) reported storm event beds with sole marks in the West Rand Group, and compared evidence there for shore-oblique and shore-parallel geostrophic currents with storm processes on modern continental shelves. However, the discrimination of tideand storm-deposited facies in Precambrian epeiric coastal environments is difficult, requiring high-resolution facies analysis (Bose and Chaudhuri, 1990) (Sections 3 and 4).
The apparent paucity of tidal influences in the Archaean Witwatersrand–Pongola deposits, and the fact that identified shoreline sediments appear to be rare (Beukes and Cairncross, 1991; Stanistreet and McCarthy, 1991; Els, 1998) are difficult to explain within an inferred epeiric sea embayment model. Evidence supports syn-Witwatersrand continental suturing during accretion of island arc and cratonic plates in the developing Kaapvaal craton (e.g. De Wit et al., 1992; McCourt, 1995), and this embayment basin may thus have been somewhat different from a classic epeiric sea setting. Perhaps Witwatersrand– Pongola inundation was partly controlled by the microplate structure of the emerging Kaapvaal craton rather than reflecting transgression across a large, relatively homogeneous cratonic terrane. The extent of inundation inferred from preserved outcrops, possibly up to 400 km inland (Fig. 6), may thus be an over-estimate. The strong association of fluvial deposits with the inferred shallow shelf sediments in the greater Witwatersrand basin, along with the observed paucity of true shoreline deposits, may point to the interaction of strongly progradational fluvial and braid-delta systems with shelf seas developed along microplate boundaries.

sections.heading: 5.2.2. Proterozoic examples
sections.text:
The Iron Ore Group in India may have been deposited in a Palaeoproterozoic epeiric embayment. Extension of Archaean basement led to the development of a shallow platform basin filled largely
by clastic sediments; evidence for extensive shallow water marine conditions includes current ripples and stromatolites (Bhattacharya, 1992).
Within the Kaapvaal craton of South Africa, the late Archaean–Palaeoproterozoic Transvaal Supergroup is thought to reflect both carbonate and clastic epeiric sea basins. The approximately 2650– 2500 Ma (Eriksson and Altermann, 1998) Ghaap– Chuniespoort (Groups) carbonate platform, one of the oldest such successions (Altermann and Nelson, 1998), covered an area in excess of 600,000 km2 (Beukes, 1987; Altermann and Wotherspoon, 1995). Thermal subsidence along pre-existing Ventersdorp Supergroup fault systems most likely promoted the Transvaal transgression, and the resultant epeiric basin is inferred to have been a seaway, probably open to the east-northeast, rather than an embayment (Clendenin, 1989). The seaway was about 1100 km long and up to 500 km wide, and basin-floor palaeoslopes, estimated at 0.12–0.2 . 0:45/ m=km (Clendenin, 1989) are compatible with the average of 0.19 m=km proposed in the Irwin (1965) model. However, in contrast to the latter model, wave, tidal and lesser storm processes appear to have characterised the Transvaal seaway, for which a distally steepened carbonate ramp setting has been proposed (Clendenin, 1989). In the succeeding clastic Pretoria Group deposits, an epeiric embayment may have developed during deposition of the Timeball Hill (Eriksson and Reczko, 1998) and Silverton (Eriksson and Reczko, 1995) Formations. The location of these two embayments and their inferred dimensions and depositional systems appear to have been similar.
An analogous carbonate platform succession, but one of Late Precambrian age (approximately 890– 775 Ma) and flat ramp affinity, is the Atar Group of the West African craton (Bernard-Sarfati and Moussine-Pouchkine, 1988). These authors recognised neither tidal influences nor palaeosalinity gradients, and they suggest that sedimentation was storm- and wave-dominated, with water depths attaining a maximum of 50–100 m below wave base. Black pyritic shales, a common early-stage epeiric sea facies (Hallam, 1981), occur at the base of the Transvaal seaway succession (Clendenin, 1989), and also in the Atar Group of West Africa. The Atar embayment had dimensions of approximately 1700 km
22 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
by 1000 km, and thus compares favourably with the Irwin (1965) model (Bernard-Sarfati and MoussinePouchkine, 1988).

sections.heading: 5.3. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
Precambrian successions interpreted as epeiric sea deposits bear a strong resemblance to examples identified in the Phanerozoic. Sedimentation processes inferred from all these deposits are analogous to those responsible for modern and ancient shelf sea successions (Sections 3 and 4). Despite the fact that epeiric seas do not represent first-order depositional systems of the same rank as others discussed in this paper, they do appear to have been important in the Precambrian rock record.
The only significant difference between Precambrian epeiric sea deposits and their Phanerozoic equivalents, is the strong association with continental sediments in the former, particularly well documented in the interbedded fluvial and shallow marine beds preserved from the Archaean Witwatersrand– Pongola embayment (e.g. Els, 1998). For the Proterozoic example discussed in this volume (Eriksson and Reczko, 1998), braid-delta-fed sedimentation systems appear to have been important in the Transvaal embayment of the Kaapvaal craton. The association of braided fluvial and shallow marine epeiric sea systems in the Precambrian presumably reflects rapid erosion of aggressively weathered continental areas marginal to the epicontinental seas, with large volumes of detritus being supplied to the coastal environments.

sections.heading: 6.1. Introduction
sections.text:
Precambrian deltas are well documented in both Archaean and Proterozoic clastic successions. The oldest recognizable deltaic facies, over 3 Ga in age, belong to the Archaean Moodies Group of the Barberton greenstone belt, South Africa (Eriksson, 1979; Heubeck and Lowe, 1994). Younger Precambrian deltaic sequences occur, for example, in northern Norway, in the Neoproterozoic Basnaering Formation of the Barents Sea Group (Siedlecka et al., 1989). Relatively recent reviews of the deltaic
environment are given by Whateley and Pickering (1989), Colella and Prior (1990) and Bhattacharya and Walker (1992).
On a large scale, Precambrian delta systems are recognised as being transitional between non-marine deposits, such as alluvial strata, and open marine shelf strata. The lack of freshwater, brackish water and seawater fauna, plant debris, coal seams, trace fossils, and bioturbation structures that are characteristic of the different subenvironments of Phanerozoic-younger delta deposits, decreases the palaeoenvironmental resolution of Precambrian delta successions. However, non-biogenic structures normally provide sufficient means for identification. Inferred Precambrian delta plain deposits exhibit the most diverse association of facies, including erosional surfaces and a variety of sedimentary structures corresponding to different flow regimes and palaeocurrent patterns. Delta front sediments may include gravity-flow products and soft-sediment deformation structures, due to the higher slope of the depositional palaeosurface and high sedimentation rates. Precambrian prodelta facies usually include deformational structures, such as convolute bedding, diapiric features and loading structures.

sections.heading: 6.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
sections.text:
Precambrian deltaic sequences are recognised on the basis of the same types of facies associations, non-biogenic sedimentary structures and lithological vertical profiles, as are known from Phanerozoicmodern delta deposits. In addition, flow regime and palaeocurrent interpretations point to a general similarity between the depositional environments and the depositional processes dominating marginal marine settings of Precambrian and younger ages (see also Sections 3 and 4). The similarity between inferred Precambrian and Phanerozoic deltaic depositional processes suggests that the development of deltaic sequences during the Precambrian was controlled by the same dynamic balance between relative sea level changes and sediment input observed in modern environments.
Thus, Precambrian deltaic sequences=lobes are characterised by the same overall coarsening-upward vertical profiles observed in Phanerozoic-modern de-
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 23
posits, showing a transition from the muddier facies of the prodelta into the sandier facies of the delta front and distributary mouth bar subenvironments, conformably or unconformably overlain by the delta plain facies. Finer-grained sediments dominated the interdistributary areas of the Precambrian delta plain subenvironment. Pebble conglomerates commonly occur at the base of the tidal channels or distributary channel-fills, as channel lag deposits. Sandstones dominate the delta plain channel-fills, as well as the delta front facies (Fig. 7). The sandstones are mostly quartz arenites and subarkoses, that may contain lithoclasts such as chert fragments. Granitic, other igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary rocks are included in the inferred Precambrian fluviodeltaic source areas (Eriksson, 1979; Siedlecka et al., 1989).
All the non-biogenic controls on delta plain channel style known from Phanerozoic-modern settings (such as topographic slope, type and quantity of sediment supply in relationship to the river transport capacity) are interpreted from Precambrian palaeoenvironments as well. However, vegetation is also an important control on channel style, generally preventing the development of braiding (Miall, 1992). Precambrian distributary channels were thus characterised by poorly consolidated banks with a consequent tendency for braided channel styles to predominate (Schumm, 1968). Inferred point bar deposits within some Precambrian distributary channel facies (e.g. Eriksson, 1979) may be ascribed to tidal processes at river mouths, producing intensive meandering above the zone of tidal influence (Coleman and Wright, 1975).
24 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
Structures or suites of structures may differ from one inferred Precambrian delta succession to another, as a function of the dominant processes (river action versus wave energy and tidal range) which controlled sediment transport, reworking and deposition (for modern and ancient examples, see Morgan, 1970; Eriksson, 1979; Siedlecka et al., 1989; Bhattacharya and Walker, 1992). Macrotidal ranges resulted in the accumulation of distal, shore-perpendicular sand bars within the delta front subenvironment, and they may be preserved as more mature sandstones in vertical successions, towards the top of the delta front facies (Fig. 7) (Eriksson, 1979). Proximal and coeval tidal channels were incised into the tidal flats of the delta plain subenvironment. Under lower tidal ranges, as wave processes became predominant, the depositional setting was characterised by the development of shore-parallel barrier islands with associated back-barrier tidal flats, washover fans and spits. When micro- and macrotidal conditions co-existed along the same coastline, as seems to have been the case during deposition of the Archaean Moodies delta sequences, mechanisms controlling the amplified tidal ranges may have included large quantities of water introduced into open-ended constrictions, embayments in the coastline, or an increase in the shelf width (Eriksson, 1979).
The outer limit of a Precambrian prodelta may be mapped by considering the relative thicknesses of the deltaic and open shelf sediments, the presence of river-sourced sediments, and the proximal limit of banded iron formations (BIF). It appears that iron precipitation was the background chemical ‘rainout’ in the >2.0 Ga shelf setting, at times of minimal clastic input from fluviodeltaic systems (Barrett and Fralick, 1989). At shallow water depths, within the Precambrian prodelta subenvironment, a continuous supply of fine-grained river-sourced sediment prevented the formation of chemical precipitates. For this reason, the proximal limit of BIF could be taken as the outer limit of a Precambrian prodelta deposit, whereas the degree of bioturbation may be used to differentiate between the fully bioturbated open shelf sediments and the at least partly laminated prodelta facies within Phanerozoic-modern settings. However, gravity-flow products, especially turbidites, may equally develop within both prodelta and open shelf subenvironments, which
makes the distinction between the two more difficult.
Phanerozoic and modern deltaic deposits display thicknesses ranging generally from a few metres to about 100 m, depending on the scale of the delta and the water depth at the time of deposition. Only in rare cases (e.g. the Mississippi delta, or the Upper Cretaceous Dunvegan deltaic sequences of northwestern Alberta: Bhattacharya and Walker, 1991, 1992), do thicknesses approach or exceed 150 m. In contrast, Precambrian deltas tended to generate sequences in excess of a few hundred metres. For example, the Basnaering delta complex of northern Norway is composed of a few stacked deltaic lobes, and records a maximum thickness of 3500 m (Siedlecka et al., 1989). In the case of the South African Moodies Group, the thickness of the delta front–mouth bar– delta plain succession exceeds 400 m (Fig. 7) (Eriksson, 1979).
These great thicknesses, together with the textural immaturity common in Precambrian deltaic sediments (e.g. Fig. 7), suggest deep water receiving basins, a high generation rate of accommodation space, close proximity of the receiving basins to the source areas, high-energy distributary channels, a high sediment supply, and efficient sediment transport. The latter three factors may have been related to the lack of continental vegetation and to the preferential development of low-sinuosity braided fluvial systems. However, other features, including preserved geometry, abundance and distribution of conglomerates, and proximity to major faults, point towards a sedimentation style related to sedimentary basins generated through active tectonics, and characterised by high subsidence rates, sharp relief and steep topographic slopes. Such basins were most likely related to active extensional fault tectonics, generated during continental rifting and subsequent opening and spreading of the oceanic floor, and represented by listric fault dominated divergent continental margins. Early response to rifting could have generated sedimentary sequences with abrupt facies changes from fluvial to deep-marine turbidites, aided by the lack of a stable continental shelf, as exemplified by the Archaean Minitaki basin of northwestern Ontario (Walker and Pettijohn, 1971). Alternatively, deposition after rifting and advance of the sea could generate thick marginal marine deposits, separating
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 25
fluvial and deep-marine strata, promoted by the existence of emerging stable continental shelves, as exemplified by the Moodies Group of South Africa (Eriksson, 1979).

sections.heading: 6.3. Braid-deltas
sections.text: Braid-deltas (Nemec and Steel, 1988) form where braided river systems prograde directly into standing bodies of water, with variable and often complex modification of alluvial deposits in the shorezone by wave and tide influences. In certain Pliocene examples, proximal upward-fining, channelised braiddelta plain deposits are easily discriminated from distal, non-channelised, upward-coarsening braiddelta front sediments (Galloway and Hobday, 1983). However, distinctions are often more subtle, particularly for non-fossiliferous Precambrian successions. Rapid Precambrian chemical weathering (Corcoran et al., 1998; Donaldson and de Kemp, 1998) and intense erosion in the absence of vegetation promoted the development of large braidplain systems characterised by high discharge rates (Section 7). Where these debouched onto broad, gently sloping Precambrian marine shelves, extensive braid-deltas commonly developed (Els, 1998). Reworking of alluvial detritus was intense in some examples, as in the case of fringing beach and tidal flat deposits in the Mesoproterozoic Waterberg Group, South Africa (Vos and Eriksson, 1977), or in the Late Precambrian successions of Arctic Norway (Hobday, 1974). More subtle combinations of tidal and alluvial facies are preserved in other examples, often related to preserved epeiric sea shorelines, examples including the Palaeoproterozoic Dwaalheuwel and Magaliesberg Formations, Transvaal Supergroup, Kaapvaal craton (Schreiber and Eriksson, 1992; Eriksson et al., 1995).

sections.heading: 6.4. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
Apart from the absence of invertebrate and plant remains, which reduces palaeoenvironmental resolution in preserved Precambrian delta successions, depositional environments, processes and facies appear to have been remarkably similar to those observed in younger settings. The absence of vegetation bordering distributary channels led to braided delta plain
systems. Precambrian delta sequences and stacked deltaic lobes display markedly greater thicknesses than their younger counterparts, as well as more texturally immature sediments. A more active, probably rift-related tectonic setting is thus often surmised, and Precambrian receiving basins are inferred to have had high subsidence rates, steep topographic slopes and sharp reliefs. High sediment supply and efficient alluvial sediment transport in pre-vegetational times probably also promoted thick deltaic deposits. Where large continental braidplain systems debouched directly onto wide, gently sloping marine shelves, braid-delta deposits commonly developed.

sections.heading: 7.1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the absence of vegetation, mechanical weathering processes would have been important in most Precambrian climatic settings, and, together with rapid chemical breakdown processes (Corcoran et al., 1998), would have produced an abundance of detritus. Given a lack of the binding action of roots, this would have been removed readily by rivers, and channel bank stability would have been low, resulting in a preponderance of broad channels with abundant bedload (e.g. Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). A braided fluvial style has thus long been regarded as the most likely for pre-vegetational times (Schumm, 1968; Cotter, 1978; Long, 1978; Sønderholm and Tirsgaard, 1998). However, distinguishing different fluvial styles requires an accumulation of evidence, because no single criterion can be considered adequate on its own (Jackson, 1978). Faster runoff rates due to the lack of vegetation in the Precambrian would have made river systems more sensitive to climatic changes, and ephemeral rivers thus probably formed in a broader climatic range than those observed today (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998).
Rainbird (1992), McCormick and Grotzinger (1993) and Miall (1996) have reviewed criteria for the distinction of fluvial from other clastic deposits in the Precambrian record. Some criteria discussed by Long (1978), such as grain size and petrographic composition, are no longer considered diagnostic. The details of cross-bed style are probably the most distinctive features of fluvial deposits. Aeolian
26 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
cross-bed styles are easily differentiated (Hunter, 1977), and aeolian sandstones normally exhibit excellent sorting and grain rounding. Fluvial cross-bedding styles are similar to those of some marine sandwaves, and ebb- or flood-dominated tidal deltas, but unimodal palaeocurrents and evidence of exposure (e.g. desiccation features) suggest fluvial channel and floodplain palaeoenvironments.
Palaeosols are common in the Precambrian nonmarine record, and are found most often at unconformities overlain by fluvial deposits. Precambrian palaeosols are of particular economic significance in the Witwatersrand basin, South Africa, where they are associated with the major gold and uranium concentrations (Button and Tyler, 1981).

sections.heading: 7.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
sections.text:
Various stages of island arc unroofing in Archaean greenstone belts were characterised by conglomerate-dominated alluvial fan or fan-delta deposits, in fault or unconformable contact with a volcano-plutonic hinterland (e.g. Mueller and Dimroth, 1987; Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). The observed abundance of trough cross-beds in conglomerate and sandstone units indicates the stream flow nature of these alluvial deposits.
