Landslides due to volcanic tremors or torrential rain in the absence of vegetation formed debris flow, hyperconcentrated flood flow and sheetflood deposits. A rapid influx of pyroclastic debris in certain cases led to congestion of the alluvial dispersal systems, causing a change in the transport mechanism, from one dominated by streams to one dominated by non-confined masswasting (Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). Reworking in the form of stream incision and normal fluvial denudation processes occurred during volcanic quiescence of the island arcs. Sandy to pebbly braidplain deposits locally overlie the fan deposits, and indicate a more subdued palaeotopography, but there is more commonly a rapid change at higher stratigraphic levels of greenstone sedimentary successions into sandy–muddy shallow marine deposits (Mueller and Dimroth, 1987).
Cratonic sedimentation began in the Archaean in some parts of the world. The Moodies Group of the Barberton greenstone belt (ca. 3.0 Ga), Kaapvaal
proto-craton in southern Africa, is amongst the earliest typically cratonic successions to be preserved (Eriksson, 1978). These alluvial deposits include matrix-supported conglomerates deposited by sediment gravity-flow processes, clast-supported stream flow conglomerates, and trough cross-bedded sandstones displaying unimodal palaeocurrent patterns. The latter are attributed to deposition on a broad fluvial plain, probably in braided channels (Eriksson, 1978).
The first appearance of large cratons was probably also that of the Kaapvaal, where the 3.0– 2.7 Ga Witwatersrand Supergroup was deposited. Although this succession encompasses lower thick epeiric sea deposits (West Rand and Mozaan Groups, Section 5.2.1), the upper Central Rand Group is dominated by sandy and conglomeratic braidplain deposits (Els, 1998) in which economically very important gold and uranium placers are hosted (Minter, 1978; Smith and Minter, 1980; Minter et al., 1988). Minter (1978) plotted mineral concentrations against palaeocurrent data and argued that the close relationship between the two types of distribution pattern indicated hydraulic control. Smith and Minter (1980) and Smith and Beukes (1983) demonstrated the local control on Central Rand palaeoplacer mineral concentrations exerted by the evolution of bars and channels in a gravel-bed braided fluvial system.
In the Proterozoic, after the widespread appearance of large cratons, and with the possibility of Early Precambrian supercontinents (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998), continental interiors probably were occupied by very large, perennial braided systems. An example from the Canadian shield, the Neoproterozoic Kuujjua Formation, developed on a braidplain greater than 150 km wide (Rainbird et al., 1992). Braidplains within the Palaeoproterozoic Dwaalheuwel and Droogedal Formations (Pretoria Group, Transvaal Supergroup, South Africa) had analogous dimensions, and terminated in vast braid-delta systems where they entered a distal lake basin (Schreiber and Eriksson, 1992). Compound cross-bed sets in the Kuujjua Formation indicate the presence of large macroforms or ‘sand-flats’, that formed in channels up to 8.5 m deep, and laterally extensive beds of fine-grained sandstone and siltstone containing abundant evidence of desiccation suggest the presence of temporary floodplain ponds (flood-basin playa lakes) up to 20 km wide
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 27
(Rainbird, 1992; see Fig. 8). Semi-perennial fluvial systems, identified in the Mesoproterozoic Eriksfjord Formation in southwestern Greenland, suggest relatively humid conditions with limited seasonal variation in rainfall (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998). These river systems appear to have had reduced discharge variability and higher water tables than modern ephemeral fluvial systems, and may reflect a fluvial style unique to the Precambrian (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998).
Sweet (1988) described a Palaeoproterozoic deposit in central Australia, which consists mostly of cosets of trough cross-bedded sandstone with interbedded plane-bedded units. Sweet drew an analogy with the Platte model of Miall (1978), which constitutes a fluvial style characterised by broad, shallow channels filled with fields of large twodimensional dunes. However, one unit contains fining-upward cycles, and Sweet focused in particular on one example of a classic ‘meandering-type’ cycle, with a lateral accretion deposit and an overlying unit
of floodplain fines. He interpreted this as a possible meandering stream deposit. The preservation of unmodified bedform formsets was tentatively attributed to rapid abandonment of a point bar by meander neck cutoff. However, this evidence cannot be regarded as a definitive demonstration of meandering style, but rather may record deposition on a meander bend in a river of otherwise indeterminate channel pattern.
The presence of fining-upward cycles and of lateral accretion (point bar) deposits, and the preservation of significant thicknesses of floodplain fines have been cited as indicators of a meandering style. However, as argued by Jackson (1978) and Miall (1980), and as observed in modern (Bristow, 1993) and ancient fluvial systems (Miall, 1996), these features are characteristic of many fluvial styles. Finingupward cycles occur wherever autogenic processes lead to a local decrease in stream competency. Lateral accretion has been described from many braided channel systems, such as the modern Brahmaputra, and the proportion of floodplain fines in a fluvial
28 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
succession is primarily governed by the size distribution of the sediment load, and is also a function of the subsidence and preservation rate of channels versus floodplains.
The interpretation of fluvial style should thus be based on the overall weight of evidence. Analysis of the internal architecture of channel and bar deposits, using the methods of architectural-element analysis on large outcrops is considered to be the best approach (Miall, 1996). Sønderholm and Tirsgaard (1998) applied these methods to the Neoproterozoic Rivieradal sandstones in eastern North Greenland. They describe fining- and thickening-upward cycles of muddy fluvial sediments, ascribed to a combination of mixed-load, braided channels and stable banks and floodplains, which formed under a humid palaeoclimate subject to limited seasonal fluctuations. A large variation in precipitation combined with high runoff rates in the absence of vegetation led to large fluctuations in the discharge of the mixed-load streams, and this is thought to have been responsible for the absence of a meandering style (Sønderholm and Tirsgaard, 1998).
The Late Precambrian Belt–Purcell Supergroups of western North America are immense sedimentary piles that developed during and following the rifting of the western margin of the continent, probably during the breakup of a Proterozoic supercontinent (Hoffman, 1991). They include thick and extensive fluvial successions formed as rift-basin successions, such as the Belt rocks in Idaho and Montana, described by Winston (1978). Alluvial fan and fluvial facies belts mapped in these rocks are up to hundreds of kilometres across, indicating the development of large depositional systems unconstrained by channel-bank confinement or basin topography. These pass downstream into argillites containing evidence of desiccation, and have been interpreted as the deposits of fluvial sheetfloods on a distal floodplain merging with a zone of broad tidal flats or lake-margin mudflats (Winston, 1978).

sections.heading: 7.3. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
Although the interpretation of fluvial style in preserved deposits of all ages is problematic, braided systems appear to have been preponderant in the Precambrian. Semi-perennial fluvial systems formed un-
der relatively humid palaeoclimatic conditions may reflect a style unique to pre-vegetational times (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998). Within Archaean greenstone belt settings, alluvial transport systems were commonly suffocated by large scale and rapid additions of pyroclastic debris (Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). The size of the fluvial braidplain systems which developed once large cratons or even supercontinents had emerged, in the Late Archaean– Palaeoproterozoic, was much greater than that generally observed in younger, vegetated environments.

sections.heading: 8.1. Introduction
sections.text:
There are no accepted facies or architectural element models for lacustrine sediments (Galloway and Hobday, 1983; Miall, 1984), and the apparent paucity of lacustrine deposits in the stratigraphic record reflects the difficulties inherent in their identification (Picard and High, 1972). Palaeosols, unconformities and preserved aeolian, fluvial and deltaic deposits are generally associated with ancient lacustrine beds of all ages (Glennie, 1972; Hobday, 1978; McGowen et al., 1979; Picard and High, 1981). Phanerozoic lake deposits are commonly identified by using palaeontology, and deposits of travertine, tufa, trona and the sodium-silicate mineral magadiite are considered diagnostic of a lacustrine setting (e.g. Reeves, 1968; Hardie et al., 1978; Hallam, 1981; Eugster, 1986; Ordonez et al., 1991). Non-fossiliferous Precambrian lacustrine sequences in which any evaporites generally are pseudomorphed and thus of uncertain affinity (Donnelly and Crick, 1988), render identification more challenging.
Essentially, lakes are small-scale models of ocean margins, with analogous shoreline products resulting from less intense wave processes (Galloway and Hobday, 1983). Intermittently, wind-induced waves comparable to their shallow marine counterparts may form in lakes, but the latter lack both marine swells and significant lunar tides (Friedman et al., 1992). Wind stress may impound lake water against one shore, and then release it, diurnally or seasonally, thus simulating the processes of open marine microtidal coasts (Galloway and Hobday, 1983). The common cyclicity of lake deposits, reflecting cli-
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 29
matic variability, is also analogous to many marine mesosequences (Friedman et al., 1992), and stromatolites tend to be common in both environments (Hallam, 1981). The discrimination of Precambrian lacustrine deposits from shallow marine and epeiric sediments is thus subtle and problematic (Hallam, 1981; Miall, 1984; Montes et al., 1985; Winston, 1986; Donnelly and Crick, 1988; Schieber, 1998).

sections.heading: 8.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
sections.text:
Associated alluvial and aeolian continental deposits have been utilised to help identify Precambrian lacustrine successions from the late Archaean (Karpeta, 1989), Palaeoproterozoic (Callaghan et al., 1991; Aspler et al., 1994), Mesoproterozoic (Unrug, 1984; Donnelly and Jackson, 1988) and Neoproterozoic (Kalliokoski, 1986). In the North Spirit Lake greenstone belt in Canada, inferred Archaean lacustrine beds are associated with alluvial fan and braided river deposits, all thought to have been laid down in a marginal basin; however, at another locality, the equivalent alluvial sediments are succeeded by submarine fan deposits (Wood, 1980), a relationship which raises doubts about the lacustrine model. The preserved thickness of Precambrian lacustrine successions does not exceed about 600 m, and is more typically only tens of metres thick (Collinson, 1983; Donnelly and Jackson, 1988; Karpeta, 1989; Eriksson and Reczko, 1995; Fairchild and Hambrey, 1995), as is also found in younger examples (e.g. Picard and High, 1972).
Saline playa lake models predominate in the literature on identified Precambrian lake successions. The oldest example is from the Rietgat Formation, Ventersdorp Supergroup in South Africa. Here, an association of bedded cherts (partly of magadiitic origin) and siltstones, with stromatolites and strong evidence of evaporite mineral formation, weak tidal activity and desiccation processes, points to an alkaline playa setting (Karpeta, 1989). These rocks occur with alluvial fan and fluvial sediments within intracratonic graben basins, formed within the 2.7 Ga Ventersdorp volcanic terrane (Van der Westhuizen et al., 1991). Geochemical evidence and preserved evaporite pseudomorphs led Martini (1990) to argue for an alkaline playa model for 2 m thick beds
associated with the š2:2 Ga Hekpoort Formation palaeosol in South Africa.
Donnelly and Jackson (1988) used strontium, carbon and sulphur isotopic data to support their saline mudflat interpretation of the Meoproterozoic Wollogorang Formation in the McArthur basin, Australia. These thin (2–5 m) evaporitic redbeds are associated with varved, organic-rich black shales, thought to represent a more distal, quiet water lake setting (Donnelly and Jackson, 1988). Thermal stratification of water layers is common in lakes, promoting the formation of various kinds of annual-layered or varved sediments (Sturm and Matter, 1978; Hallam, 1981). However, rhythmites may also reflect an alternation of suspension deposition and aeolian action (Rogers and Astin, 1991).
An association of desiccation polygons, halite pseudomorphs, stromatolites and ripple marks led Collinson (1983) to propose a saline lake model for Mesoproterozoic strata in eastern North Greenland. In the Neoproterozoic, a number of similar playa lake deposits have been identified, using evaporite pseudomorphs and relics, a mixture of fine clastic and chemical sediments, geochemical data, Ediacaran fossils and fluid inclusion studies (Kalliokoski, 1986; Porada and Behr, 1988; Fairchild and Hambrey, 1995).
In contrast to the relative success in identification of saline lake sediments, discrimination of hydrologically open and more permanent lakes in the Precambrian record is fraught with problems (e.g. Winston, 1986; Schieber, 1998; Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). Despite the lower fetch of lacustrine waves, which promotes shallow wave base conditions and less mature wave-influenced sands, lacustrine beaches, barriers and spits strongly resemble their marine counterparts (Tucker, 1991). Longshore drift is also relatively common in hydrologically open lakes (Martel and Gibling, 1991). Clastic lake shoreline features may even form due to wind funnelling around the margins of small, shallow, closed, saline lakes, such as in Holocene Lake Bogoria, Kenya (Renaut and Owen, 1991). Lacustrine storm-related hummocky cross-stratification has a noticeably shorter wavelength (40–80 cm) than that formed in open marine shelf settings (Galloway and Hobday, 1983). Lake deltas are mostly river-dominated and elongated, with well developed mouth bars due to weak tidal
30 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
and wind action and high fluvial sediment supply (Collinson, 1978; Galloway and Hobday, 1983). Lacustrine delta sequences are normally also much reduced in scale compared to marine deltas, and are mostly of the Gilbert-type (Tucker, 1991).
For the Mesoproterozoic Mporokosa Group in Zambia, Unrug (1984) based his perennial lacustrine interpretation on an intracratonic setting, a preserved thickness of 20–600 m, associated fluvial and aeolian deposits, extensive preserved desiccated mudrocks, predominant wave ripple marks and strong evidence for repeated shoreline migration within a small stratigraphic thickness. Mueller and Corcoran (1998) use a combination of preserved geometry, tectonic setting and associated continental facies, to suggest that stacked metre-thick argillite units with internal laminations, graded beds and ripples, found within late-orogenic basin sequences in the late Archaean Superior Province, Canada, are of lacustrine origin.
Up to 400 m of sediments are preserved in the >2.09 Ga Whiterock Member, Kinga Formation (Hurwitz Group, Canada) and outcrops indicate a minimum areal extent of 100,000 km2 (Aspler et al., 1994). Such geometry, in conjunction with uniformity of the sedimentary facies in the Whiterock Member, strongly supports a lacustrine interpretation. Application of analytical and empirical techniques to the predominant short-spaced ripples and parallel stratification in these supermature sandstones suggests that water depths averaging 2 cm–2 m were maintained over large areas for long periods, and evidence is lacking for either tidal or evaporitic conditions (Aspler et al., 1994). The Whiterock Member probably was deposited in a lake within a large, shallow, non-evaporitic wetland, under an equatorial palaeoclimate (Aspler et al., 1994).
When sufficient sedimentary structures which allow empirical estimation of factors such as wave periods and water depth are preserved, as in the case of the Whiterock Member, interpretation of Early Precambrian non-saline lake deposits becomes much more convincing. However, other possible Precambrian open lake deposits, particularly those with evidence of tidal activity, remain problematic. An example is the Palaeoproterozoic Strubenkop Formation (Pretoria Group, Transvaal Supergroup, South Africa). This unit is preserved over an area of ap-
proximately 68,000 km2, and has an average thickness of 100–200 m. It has a sharp basal contact with alluvial–fluvial deposits, which exhibit inverse thickness relationships with the Strubenkop lithologies, thus implying that they are lateral facies equivalents of each other (Eriksson and Reczko, 1995), and is overlain erosively by fluvial (Fig. 9) and marine sheet sandstones (Eriksson et al., 1993).
The Strubenkop Formation essentially comprises an upward-coarsening succession of interlaminated pyritic mudstones and siltstones, with subordinate arkosic to argillaceous sandstones; sedimentary structures mainly comprise wave ripples, flaser structures and thin planar stratification, with less common mudcracks, channel-fills, soft-sediment deformation structures and cross-strata (Fig. 9) (Eriksson and Reczko, 1995). Palaeocurrent patterns are bimodal to polymodal. The textural and mineralogical immaturity of the subordinate sandstones is unusual for a shallow marine setting, but the evidence for tidal activity is equally so for an alternative lacustrine palaeoenvironment (Fig. 9). A protected shallow marine embayment model, with inefficient microtidal reworking of continental detritus, and a perennial lacustrine interpretation, encompassing wind-tidal flats, are equally applicable to the Strubenkop Formation. The thickness of this unit is compatible with a lake deposit, but the overlying fluvial–marine units do not help discriminate between the two alternatives.
Application of boron contents to differentiate shallow marine from lacustrine sediments has been used in the Pretoria Group (Eriksson et al., 1996), where an extensive sampling programme throughout the stratigraphic section and across the basin was carried out. This study indicated an alternation of transgressive marine (epeiric) and continental deposits within the Pretoria Group, and suggested a lacustrine character for the Strubenkop Formation. However, boron contents respond to a multitude of controlling factors (Eriksson et al., 1996), limiting their use in Precambrian successions.

sections.heading: 8.3. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
The preponderance of apparently ephemeral, or at least partly arid lake deposits within the geological literature on Precambrian lacustrine settings
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 31
may be a reflection of the generally warmer climatic conditions inferred for most of the Archaean and Proterozoic. The increase in evaporite and redbed deposits within the post-2.3 Ga Precambrian record (Section 2.4) is consistent with common saline lake development. Apart from this possible contrast, there do not appear to have been any significant differences between Precambrian lacustrine sediments and their Phanerozoic-modern equivalents.

sections.heading: 9.1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ergs are mostly situated in the interiors of large continents within 30º of the Equator, and grade into marginal alluvial fans, ephemeral rivers and lakes, or arid coastlines (Wilson, 1973; Miall, 1984). Migration of wind ripples forms inversely graded ripple
32 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
laminations, unique to aeolian as opposed to subaqueous transport systems (Hunter, 1977; Kocurek and Dott, 1981), thereby enabling identification of wind-deposited sediments of all ages to be made with confidence. A combination of inversely graded strata, adhesion ripples and warts is considered diagnostic of aeolian processes within Precambrian successions (Eriksson and Simpson, 1998).
The predominantly warm palaeoclimatic conditions inferred for the Precambrian (Section 2.4), in conjunction with the absence of vegetation prior to the Silurian, suggest that desert-forming conditions and hence aeolian deposits should have been relatively abundant (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998). Lack of identified aeolian deposits older than 2.7 Ga, their apparent scarcity prior to 1.8 Ga, and evidence for an increasing abundance near and after 1.8 Ga (Eriksson and Simpson, 1998) must thus be significant.
Limited cratonic terranes prior to 2.5 Ga probably restricted the potential for large ergs to form, and supercontinent assembly (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998) may have influenced their apparently extensive development at about 1.8 Ga (Eriksson and Simpson, 1998). Other explanations for the temporal distribution of Precambrian aeolianites include non-recognition (e.g. Ross, 1983), or, alternatively, a preservational bias (Eriksson and Simpson, 1998). Ross (1983) suggested that Precambrian humid fluvial systems may have inhibited erg formation, due to a high rate of lateral migration of river systems, rapid intra-river channel switching and more common flooding. Ephemeral flash floods would also have tended to prevent the preservation of aeolian sediments formed within semiarid palaeoenvironments; in contrast, more humid, semi-perennial fluvial systems, characterised by higher groundwater levels, would have promoted preservation of aeolianites (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998).
Enhanced cloud cover in the Early Precambrian, due to a greater relative surface area of water and due to the greenhouse effect, may have affected climates (Section 2.4) such that moist atmospheric conditions affected aeolian transport and deposition. In addition, a CO2-rich atmosphere would most likely have had smaller temperature gradients with changes in latitude, and this could have led to reduced wind activity (Frakes, 1979). However, this might have
been offset by the faster rotation of the Earth in the Early Precambrian (Section 2.2). Also, the generally higher temperatures inferred for the Early Precambrian may have increased latitudinal gradients during the Archaean (Walker, 1982), thereby negating the possible influence of a CO2-rich atmosphere. It is thus difficult to infer pre-2.0 Ga wind conditions with any confidence, and an explanation for the apparent scarcity of major ergs in the Early Precambrian awaits further investigation.

sections.heading: 9.2. Processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
sections.text:
Ventifacts found within the 2.9–2.7 Ga Central Rand Group, Witwatersrand Supergroup, South Africa indicate wind erosion, but no aeolianites are preserved within this basin (Els, 1998). An inferred wind deposit is identified in the late Archaean Abitibi greenstone belt in northeastern Canada (Hyde, 1980). However, the criteria used are equivocal and the small-scale diagnostic aeolian structures of Hunter (1977) were not taken into account. Aspler and Chiarenzelli (1997) describe a more plausible inferred erg deposit from the Maguse Member, Kinga Formation in the 2.45–2.1 Ga Hurwitz Group, Northwest Territories, Canada. These authors discuss evidence for dunes superimposed on draas, multiple bounding surfaces, possible barchanoid or aklé dune forms, interdune deposits including a possible deflation lag, as well as documented adhesion structures and aeolian granule ripples. Apart from the Maguse Member and an aeolianite identified in the approximately 2.1 Ga Magondi Supergroup in Zimbabwe (Master, 1991), no convincingly documented wind deposits are reported until near the end of the Palaeoproterozoic, with the Waterberg Group of South Africa being amongst the oldest, at about 1.9–1.7 Ga (Callaghan et al., 1991).
The Makgabeng Formation of the Waterberg Group is inferred to be a preserved erg deposit. It is underlain and overlain by braided fluvial formations, and passes laterally into inferred throughflow lake sediments showing evidence of emergence (Callaghan et al., 1991). The Makgabeng sandstones are fine- to medium-grained, well sorted with high grain sphericity and consist of mineralogically mature orthoquartzites (Meinster and Tickell, 1975).
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 33
Excellent grain roundness and sorting are similarly typical of modern erg sands (e.g. Lancaster, 1983). Downwind decreases in grain size and concomitant increases in sorting also characterise many ergs, both modern and ancient (Langford and Chan, 1989).
The characteristic large-scale cross-bedding in the Makgabeng Formation is comparable to that observed in most Phanerozoic erg deposits (e.g. Friedman et al., 1992), and has set thicknesses of 2–10 m, foreset angles mostly of about 19º (maximum 38º), low-angle bounding surfaces (Fig. 10) and exhibits slump structures. Support for erg models is also provided by preserved interdune deposits, such as deflationary lags and scours, evaporites, wind ripples, adhesion features, raindrop imprints and a host of wet interdune sediments (Ahlbrandt and Fryberger, 1981; Kocurek and Dott, 1981). Uncommon desiccated mudrock lenses, adhesion warts and channel-fills in the Waterberg deposits suggest dry and wet interdune deposits (Meinster and Tickell, 1975; Callaghan et al., 1991).
The identification of inversely graded ripple laminations (Hunter, 1977) would confirm the inferred
aeolian origin of the Makgabeng sandstones beyond doubt. Such structures are identified in 1.8–1.74 Ga aeolianites described within the Mount Isa Inlier in Australia (Jackson et al., 1990; Simpson and Eriksson, 1993; Eriksson and Simpson, 1998). These authors identify both dune and interdune deposits and document the interaction of fluvial, shallow marine and aeolian processes, with the latter being part of transgressive systems tracts.
The 1.6 Ga Hornby Bay Group in northwestern Canada has an association of Precambrian desert sediments comprising wadi fan conglomerates and braided stream arenites, as well as aeolian deposits with the inversely graded ripple laminae typical of wind ripples (Ross, 1983). Ross suggests that deposition was by both straight-crested and sinuous transverse dunes, with evidence of superimposed bedforms. Although inverse grading of ripple-formed laminae sensu Hunter (1977) was difficult to identify in the correlative Thelon Formation, barchanoid dune fields were apparently associated locally with braided stream deposits during deposition of this unit (Jackson et al., 1984).
34 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
Meso- to Neoproterozoic aeolianites are relatively common, with some examples being more readily demonstrated than others, through the identification of inversely graded wind ripple stratification. Pulvertaft (1985) was able to identify dune deposits with three orders of bounding surfaces, as well as convincing wet and dry interdune sediments in the Mesoproterozoic Dala sandstone in Sweden. An example of less well constrained inferred palaeodune sediments is that of the approximately coeval Calyie Formation in the Bangemall Basin, Australia. Largescale cross-beds here, which were compared to the structures in the Waterberg Group, are ascribed to either a coastal aeolian origin, or to an alternative shallow marine genesis (Goode and Hall, 1981). Thin aeolianites occur interbedded with semi-ephemeral fluvial sand sheets in the Mesoproterozoic Eriksfjord Formation of southwestern Greenland (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998). Wind ripple lamination and adhesion structures characterise these aeolian sand sheets, which accumulated under a palaeoclimate with limited seasonal variation, and which were preserved due to the unusual fluvial style and higher groundwater table.
In the Neoproterozoic Sullavai Group of southern India, Chakraborty and Chaudhuri (1993) have reported aeolian reworking of fluvial floodplain sediments, with overlying erg interior and erg margin deposits; these authors were able to infer dome-shaped, transverse and crescentic dune forms, interdune deposits and superimposed bedforms. Application of studies of modern aquifer air release features in Saudi Arabian wadis to the Neoproterozoic Torridon Group of Scotland, indicates analogous semiarid alluvial sedimentation systems and suggests, further, that it may be possible to distinguish initial, muddy ephemeral flood deposits from those succeeding them later in the wet season, in these Precambrian rocks (McManus and Bajabaa, 1998).

sections.heading: 9.3. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
Evidence suggests that aeolian processes and products have been essentially the same throughout geological time, but that ergs only became abundant at approximately 1.8 Ga and thereafter. The noticeable temporal control on desert sediments in the Precambrian (Eriksson and Simpson, 1998) may
be ascribed to numerous factors: poor recognition or preservation prior to 1.8 Ga, restricted continental terrains in the late Archaean, possible supercontinent assembly at about 1.8 Ga, laterally extensive humid fluvial systems, and the poorly understood effect of Precambrian palaeoclimates on wind systems prior to this age. Semi-ephemeral fluvial systems with limited seasonal variation and high groundwater levels locally preserved aeolianites in the Middle Precambrian (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998).

sections.heading: 10.1. Introduction
sections.text:
Glaciations reflect the interplay of atmospheric, tectonic, oceanic, astronomic and biologic processes, and the widespread distribution of glacial deposits records global events (e.g. Ojakangas, 1988). Whereas processes of erosion, transportation and deposition in certain Precambrian environments may have differed markedly relative to modern settings, as outlined in some of the previous sections, those in glacial depositional systems may have been similar. Not only do Precambrian glacial deposits per se yield baselines to evaluate climatic change well before the recent past, they also provide distinctive markers for Precambrian global sequence stratigraphy, and they constitute potential piercing points for reconstructing Precambrian supercontinents (e.g. Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998).
The use of glacial deposits as distinctive markers for intracontinental correlation of Precambrian sequences has had a long history (Young, 1970; Fairchild and Hambrey, 1995), dating back to at least Blackwelder (1926) and Coleman (1926) who proposed links between the Huronian (Ontario) and Snowy Pass (Wyoming) Supergroups. Glacial sequences have proven valuable for the intercontinental correlations required for reconstruction of Neoproterozoic supercontinents (e.g. Young, 1992, 1995b; Li et al., 1995, 1996). World maps of Precambrian ice-flow indicators and glacigenic facies, similar to those prepared for Gondwana (e.g. Vaslet, 1990), provide future challenges. They hold potential for the refinement of supercontinent reconstructions and, in feedback, for helping to establish Neoproterozoic ice sheet dynamics.
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 35
Syntheses of Precambrian glacial deposits that update the now classic catalogues of Hambrey and Harland (1981, 1985) have been presented recently by Eyles (1993), and Eyles and Young (1994). For the Palaeo- and Neoproterozoic, glacial deposits are represented worldwide, but only isolated possible occurrences have been reported from the Archaean (Page, 1981; Von Brunn and Gold, 1993).

sections.heading: 10.2. Glacigenic and periglacial processes and products: Precambrian and younger settings
sections.text:
The following concentrates on the signatures that glaciers and related cold-climates impart to the rock record, rather than evaluating the extent to which glaciers were active as direct depositional agents. Hence, we use the term ‘glacigenic’ in a broad sense to refer to any deposit for which a glacial imprint may be identified, recognising that the immediate sedimentary products of glaciers may be extensively reworked and ultimately deposited in other settings (e.g. Nystuen, 1985). For details, the reader is referred to reviews by Brodzikowski and van Loon (1991), Eyles and Eyles (1992), Eyles (1993), Hambrey (1994), Young (1995a) and Miller (1996), and to collections edited by Goldthwait and Matsch (1989), Dowdeswell and Scourse (1990), Anderson and Ashley (1991), Dardis and McCabe (1994), Warren and Croot (1994), and Menzies (1995a,b). Additional discussions regarding terminology, including working classifications of glacigenic sediments and rocks, are in Dreimanis (1983, 1988), Hicock (1990), and Moncrieff and Hambrey (1990).
Table 1 lists hand specimen to outcrop-scale features useful in the recognition and reconstruction of glacial and related cold-climate settings, commonly cited causative mechanisms, and selected Precambrian examples. Periglacial features are included because they may be equally important as glacigenic indicators in the reconstruction of ancient cold-climate belts. For example, in the Padlei Formation (Hurwitz Group, Northwest Territories, Canada), unequivocal data demonstrating the presence of glacial ice are lacking, but cold-climate indicators are abundant, suggesting deposition on the periglacial fringe of a Palaeoproterozoic continental glacier, considered by Young (1970, 1973) to have occupied much of what is now North America (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1997).
In addition, periglacial structures mark sequence bounding surfaces (Proust and Deynoux, 1994), and fossil sand-wedges have been used to estimate mean annual air temperature, seasonality, aridity and timescale of climatic oscillation (Williams and Tonkin, 1985; Williams, 1994). Major element geochemistry is not listed in Table 1, but is a potentially useful tool (Young, 1973, 1995a). For example, Nesbitt and Young (1982) introduced the Chemical Index of Alteration (CIA) as a measure of chemical weathering, and demonstrated that low values from glacial intervals in the 2.4–2.3 Ga Huronian Supergroup are consistent with cold climates (see also applications by Marmo and Ojakangas, 1984; Kohonen and Marmo, 1992; Strand and Laajoki, 1993; Von Brunn and Gold, 1993).
As is apparent from Table 1, some features form in more than one glacial or cold-climate setting (polished and striated pavements, soft-sediment striation surfaces, clast pavements, preferred clast orientations, dropstones, till pellets, diamictites). Also, some may not necessarily be related to glaciers or cold climates. For example: striated clasts may reflect clast–clast interaction in non-glacial debris flows (e.g. Harrington, 1971; Schermerhorn, 1974); varve-like rhythmites may be the result of nonglacial dilute turbidity or contour currents (e.g. Piper and Stow, 1991; Ghibaudo, 1992); sandstone dykes resembling periglacial sand wedges may be generated by a variety of non-frost related mechanisms (e.g. Aspler and Donaldson, 1986a; compare Eyles and Clark, 1985 to Spencer, 1985); soft-sediment deformation with isoclinal folds and low-angle detachments is common in subaqueous slope settings (e.g. Maltman, 1994); and, a topic of past (e.g. Schermerhorn, 1974) and ongoing (Eyles, 1993, pp. 82–83; Von Brunn and Gold, 1993; Williams and Schmidt, 1996) concern, diamictites are commonly deposited by non-glacial debris flows. An alternative interpretation of glacigenic diamictites as possible meteorite impact ejecta is not considered to be valid (Williams, 1998). Thus, because of possible uncertainties regarding individual features, an assemblage of indicators is generally required to confirm a glacial or cold-climate setting or to establish specific subenvironments, and detailed analysis of facies geometry is generally needed.

lish the three-dimensional context of specific facies and to distinguish between subenvironments within broader glacial depositional systems. Some examples from the Precambrian are: (1) glacioterrestrial systems, with incised canyon (Levy et al., 1994), till (sensu stricto, Spencer, 1985; Mustard and Donaldson, 1987a; Young and Gostin, 1988), glaciofluvial and deltaic (Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Fralick and Miall, 1989), glaciolacustrine (Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1997), and glacioaeolian (Williams and Tonkin, 1985; Deynoux et al., 1989) components; (2) glaciomarine systems (Eyles et al., 1985; Miall, 1985; Strand and Laajoki, 1993; Link et al., 1994); and (3) transitional systems, where glaciers directly entered marine water, forming either grounded ice cliffs or floating ice masses (Mustard and Donaldson, 1987b; Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Matsch and Ojakangas, 1991; Young and Gostin, 1991; Link et al., 1994).
Many Neoproterozoic glacigenic successions are interbedded with carbonate rocks (e.g. Kennedy, 1996), originating as primary cold-water (e.g. Walter and Bauld, 1983; Fairchild et al., 1989; Davison and Hambrey, 1996) and=or as resedimented deposits (e.g. Young and Gostin, 1988; Fairchild, 1993; Crossing and Gostin, 1994). A carbonate association does not preclude a glacial origin nor demand a lowpalaeolatitude palaeogeography (e.g. Nelson, 1988, and see below).
Moving to the scale of an entire ice sheet, zones of glacial erosion, glacial deposition and proglacial deposition radiate from Quaternary ice divides (e.g. in North America: Shilts et al., 1987). Numerous models have been developed to account for these zones (for review see Hughes, 1995; Boulton, 1996). Most emphasise ice-sheet dynamics and the basal thermal regime, to evaluate whether ice sheets were wetbased (warm or temperate glaciers, at or above pressure melting point), dry-based (cold or polar glaciers, below pressure melting point and frozen to bed) or polythermal (e.g. sub-polar glaciers with varying thermal conditions: Menzies, 1995c; Menzies and Shilts, 1995). However, Aylsworth and Shilts (1989) stress that a consideration of bedrock geology has to be integrated into ice-sheet dynamic models. To date, regional reconstructions for the Precambrian have been limited to identification of ice divides and extent of ice sheets (Visser, 1971; Young, 1973;
Spencer, 1975; Deynoux, 1985; Nystuen, 1985; Karfunkel and Hoppe, 1988; Ojakangas, 1988). This is not surprising given that, in addition to the low preservation potential of glacioterrestrial systems, many of the features whereby ancient glaciations are recognised are the products of warm-based or polythermal ice sheets. Because cold-based glaciers are capable of occupying vast areas, yet may leave no direct record of their former presence (e.g. Holmund and Näslund, 1994; Kleman, 1994), areas of non-deposition will have to be integrated into the three-dimensional geometry of preserved deposits, in attempts to establish possible Quaternary-like zones for Precambrian ice sheets.

sections.heading: 10.3. Causes of glaciations and the Precambrian
sections.text:
Precambrian glacial systems provide evidence of global climates and causes of climatic change on time scales orders of magnitude greater than those normally considered by workers studying Quaternary and future climates (Young, 1991, 1995a; Socci, 1992). Secular changes during the Precambrian (in solar luminosity, atmospheric composition, rate of Earth’s rotation, area of land exposed to weathering, heat production, biology, and possibly, Earth’s obliquity; Section 2) constitute a backdrop to processes invoked for Phanerozoic glaciations. Thus, although glacigenic processes may not have been markedly different throughout Earth history, the Precambrian was a time of unique conditions which affected glacial and non-glacial states (e.g. Williams, 1998).
Glacial deposits are represented worldwide from the Palaeo- and Neoproterozoic, but with reports of only isolated possible occurrences from the Archaean (Page, 1981; Von Brunn and Gold, 1993), large parts of the Precambrian appear to have been non-glaciated (e.g. Young, 1991). As stated by Young (1991, p. 100) the “suggested causes of glaciation are much more numerous than the glaciations themselves.” Many causes operate on various time scales in a complex interplay of both positive and negative feedbacks (for review see Socci, 1992). Below we examine some of the factors that may have contributed to glacial=non-glacial intervals in the Precambrian.
In apparent contradiction to the virtual absence of Archaean glacial deposits, models of solar evolu-
P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53 39
tion indicate that the Sun’s luminosity was only ca. 70% of its present value near the beginning of the Archaean, predicting a frigid early Earth (e.g. Newman and Rood, 1977; Gough, 1981; Kasting, 1993) (Sections 2.2 and 2.4). This paradox is most commonly explained by invoking higher concentrations of greenhouse gases, notably CO2 (e.g. Kasting, 1993; Des Marais, 1994), although the maximum limits of CO2 based on theoretical compensation for reduced solar luminosity (Kasting, 1993) are considerably greater than estimates based on analysis of pre-ca. 2.2 Ga palaeosols (Rye et al., 1995) (Section 2.2). High levels of atmospheric CO2 may have been maintained in the Archaean, due to minimal drawdown by global weathering and biotic fixation as a result of minimal exposure of land surfaces (Marshall et al., 1988; Worsley and Kidder, 1991; Jenkins et al., 1993), if the volume of continental crust was not significantly less (see Armstrong, 1991). Greater radiogenic heat flow and a faster rate of Earth’s rotation (resulting in reduced cloud cover and decreased albedo; Jenkins et al., 1993) would also have encouraged global warming.
By the end of the Archaean, solar luminosity was still significantly less than at present (ca. 90% of modern value; Gough, 1981). Applying concepts regarding the effects of supercontinents on the atmosphere and hydrosphere (Fischer, 1984) to the Palaeoproterozoic (Worsley et al., 1986; Young, 1991, 1995a; Hoffman, 1992), the first appearance of widespread glacial deposits may have been due to the assembly, near the end of the Archaean, of the supercontinents Zimvaalbara (Zimbabwe, Kaapvaal and Pilbara cratons: Stanistreet, 1993; Cheney, 1996) and Kenorland (including parts of the Slave, Rae, Hearne, Wyoming, Superior, and Nain provinces, Siberia and the Baltic Shield: Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998). Emergence of high-standing supercontinents, buoyant above large-scale mantle upwellings (Gurnis, 1988), would have led to drawdown of greenhouse CO2 by weathering of extensively exposed land masses (Marshall et al., 1988). Under modern conditions, up to 80% of CO2 drawdown is achieved by weathering (Houghton and Woodwell, 1989). Continental biomass may have been more extensive in the Palaeoproterozoic than is generally appreciated (Ohmoto, 1996), and although biotic drawdown was probably of secondary importance,
abundant soil biota could have accelerated weathering by generating humic acids (see Schwartzman and Volk, 1989). Together with low rates of CO2 degassing (low rates of seafloor spreading) and high global albedo (low sea level), weathering of Palaeoproterozoic supercontinent(s) would have led to an ‘icehouse state’ (Fischer, 1984).
Debate surrounding low-latitude glaciations has centred on the Neoproterozoic (see below). But a low-palaeolatitude determination of ca. 11 š 5º for the ca. 2.2 Ga Ongeluk lavas on the Kaapvaal craton, which conformably overlie glacigenic deposits of the Makganyene Formation (Evans et al., 1997), nearequatorial palaeolatitudes (Buchan and Halls, 1990) from the Kaminak dykes (ca. 2.45 Ga: Heaman, 1994) unconformably beneath the Hurwitz Group in the Hearne Province, and low (3–17º) palaeolatitudes (Bates and Halls, 1991) for the Matachewan dykes (ca. 2.47 Ga: Heaman, 1997) in the Superior Province, are consistent with low-latitude Huronian glaciation, a possibility considered by Donaldson et al. (1973). If valid, a low-latitude ‘ringworld’ continental configuration could have contributed to global cooling (Marshall et al., 1988; Worsley and Kidder, 1991; but see also Crowley and Baum, 1993).
Young (1991) proposed a negative feedback mechanism to account for interbedding of glacigenic rocks with those bearing evidence of intense chemical weathering in the Palaeoproterozoic Huronian Supergroup. Accordingly, covering of land surfaces by glaciers and diminished temperatures would have reduced chemical weathering and permitted CO2 buildup, climatic amelioration and ice-sheet retreat. Renewed intense weathering would have repeated the cycle. Palaeoproterozoic glacial cycles may have terminated with supercontinent fragmentation at ca. 2.1–2.0 Ga (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998), at which time the world entered a ‘greenhouse state’ (Fischer, 1984), with high CO2 levels from diminished weathering (high sea level), increased seafloor spreading and subduction (increased volcanically produced CO2), and from decreased albedo.
Mesoproterozoic supercontinents such as ‘Atlantica’ and ‘Nena’ (see Rogers, 1996) should have given rise to glaciation and the apparent glacial gap in the Mesoproterozoic is puzzling (Young, 1991). The gap may be the result of unusually widespread anorogenic magmatism contributing sufficient CO2
40 P.G. Eriksson et al. / Sedimentary Geology 120 (1998) 5–53
to the atmosphere to balance drawdown by weathering (Young, 1991, 1995a).
At ca. 800 Ma, solar luminosity was approximately 94% of its present value (Gough, 1981). The Neoproterozoic landmasses were subjected to at least two major glacial episodes: Sturtian–Rapitan (ca. 750–700 Ma) and Maronian–Varangian–Ice Brook (ca. 610–590 Ma). The possibility exists of both older (Hambrey and Harland, 1985) and younger (Eyles, 1993; Young, 1995b) episodes. Like the Palaeoproterozoic, the existence and demise of Neoproterozoic supercontinent(s) may have been a first-order cause (e.g. Worsley et al., 1986; Young, 1991, 1995b). In addition, Young (1991, 1995b) has stressed the link between some Neoproterozoic glacial deposits and rift settings and suggested that enhanced weathering along the flanks of rift shoulder uplifts may have been a significant local control. Major Neoproterozoic glacial=non-glacial episodes were attributed by Young (1991) to the negative feedback mechanism cited above for the Palaeoproterozoic; smaller-scale cycles have been related to Milankovitch modulations (Hambrey, 1983; Proust and Deynoux, 1994).
Controversy regarding low-latitude Neoproterozoic glaciation, a proposition introduced over 30 years ago to account for palaeomagnetic results and the common association of glacigenic and carbonate rocks (Harland, 1964), continues unabated (e.g. Meert and van der Voo, 1994, 1995; Williams et al., 1995; Torsvik et al., 1996; Williams, 1998). Near-equatorial glaciation, close to sea level, is well documented for at least the Elatina Formation (Maronian) in the Adelaide Geosyncline (Williams, 1996, 1998), and thus a modern-day latitudinal control may not apply. Global (pole-to-pole) glaciation has been proposed as an explanation for low-latitude glaciation, but this hypothesis is problematic (Williams, 1998). Equally contested is the theory that the Earth’s obliquity decreased throughout the Precambrian, dropping below 54º at ca. 600–540 Ma, at which time present-day climatic zones would have prevailed (Williams, 1993, 1998). With high obliquity, Earth’s climatic zones would have been reversed from those of the Phanerozoic, favouring low-latitude glaciation (Williams, 1993, 1998). As an explanation for possible low-latitude glaciation as well as extreme seasonality, high obliquity alone
cannot cause glaciation and the theoretical basis of changing obliquity is independent of glaciations (Williams, 1993, 1994). Further palaeomagnetic and sedimentological data are needed to test the large obliquity hypothesis (Williams, 1998).

sections.heading: 10.4. Significant differences in the Precambrian
sections.text:
As discussed by other contributors to this volume, the absence of land vegetation likely had profound effects on many Precambrian depositional systems. In contrast, noting that modern proglacial environments are commonly cited as analogs for humid, non-vegetated Precambrian landscapes, and that most of the processes outlined in Section 10.2 are taken from Quaternary and modern settings, Precambrian glacigenic depositional systems may not have been very different from those in the Phanerozoic (as suggested by Dreimanis, 1983). There are at least two possible exceptions. Firstly, a greater preservational bias in favour of glaciomarine deposits would be expected in the Precambrian, without land vegetation to impede runoff and stabilise continental sediments. Secondly, loess deposits which fringe continental areas covered by Quaternary ice sheets (see Pye, 1995, for review), are rarely reported from the Precambrian (but see Edwards, 1979; Fralick and Miall, 1989). This is likely due to the absence of land plants, which suppress both deflation and reworking (e.g. Dalrymple et al., 1985).
Variation in atmospheric CO2, linked to ca. 400 Ma cycles of supercontinent assembly and fragmentation, and superimposed on a secular increase in solar luminosity and a decrease in CO2, collectively appear to have been the major control of Precambrian glacial and non-glacial states. To the extent that intense global weathering was a consequence of tectonic uplift, geodynamic control in the Precambrian is similar to long-standing models envisaged for major Cenozoic glaciation (see Raymo, 1991, 1994). Evaluation of factors like oceanic circulation and the presence or absence of spillways, and application of sophisticated general circulation models (‘GCMs’) such as for Phanerozoic sequences (e.g. Price et al., 1995), must await refined palaeogeographic reconstructions (see initial attempt by Jenkins et al., 1993).

sections.heading: 11. Conclusions
sections.text:
Despite many similarities between Precambrian and Phanerozoic-modern sedimentation systems (e.g. McManus and Bajabaa, 1998), there are also important inherent differences. The significance of some apparent differences is difficult to determine. For example, the temporal distribution of aeolian deposits in the Precambrian probably reflects some combination of limited available continental surface areas, pre-vegetative fluvial systems, supercontinent assembly, climatic conditions and atmospheric character (Eriksson and Simpson, 1998). Alternatively, this absence of unequivocal wind-deposited sediments may merely be a result of non-recognition or non-preservation (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998). More obvious differences include the absence of plants and invertebrate fossils in Precambrian delta deposits; the recognition of detailed delta subenvironments is thus complicated, delta plain channels were most likely braided, and generally thicker delta sequences in the Precambrian may be ascribed to more active tectonic settings. Similarly, pre-vegetational alluvial channel systems were almost certainly braided as well (e.g. Sønderholm and Tirsgaard, 1998); their predominantly quartz arenitic character may reflect recycling or aggressive weathering under the influence of a CO2-rich atmosphere (Corcoran et al., 1998; Donaldson and de Kemp, 1998). As micro-cratons emerged from greenstone terrane amalgamation, alluvial systems developed within small, fault-controlled basins were subject to congestion or even suffocation due to catastrophic influx of volcanic material (Mueller and Corcoran, 1998). Semi-ephemeral fluvial systems were possibly unique to pre-vegetative times and their associated raised groundwater levels may have enhanced preservation of thin, interbedded aeolian sand sheets (Tirsgaard and Øxnevad, 1998). Braid-delta systems, formed where large braidplains passed directly onto wide and gently sloping marine shelves (Els, 1998), were common in the Precambrian.
Precambrian shelf and shoreface sediments, of both wave=storm and tidal affinity, suggest the possibility of more uniform shallow marine circulation systems than in younger environments, or that Precambrian shelf environments were wide and sloped gently seawards. This might also account for the
apparent scarcity of Precambrian foreshore deposits, particularly those reflecting barrier island systems; however, poor preservation and concomitant reduced palaeoenvironmental resolution must always be a factor in the Precambrian sedimentary record. The latter factors are particularly applicable to Precambrian lacustrine deposits, although discrimination between such deposits and shallow marine sediments is difficult for rocks of all ages (e.g. Schieber, 1998). Saline lakes may have been more abundant in the Precambrian, due to inferred generally warmer palaeoclimatic conditions.
Precambrian tidal flats appear to have been characterised by poorly confined drainage channels, which formed sand sheet deposits, easily confused with fluvial or offshore tidal sand sheets. Regional studies of preserved Precambrian shallow marine basins are needed to establish the facies architecture and systems tracts which formed the successions. These should help to determine whether Precambrian shelves were indeed wide and gently sloping features without barrier island systems. However, epeiric seas may have been relatively common in the Precambrian (e.g. Eriksson and Reczko, 1998), particularly as cratons began to develop, and these poorly understood palaeoenvironments will complicate studies of Precambrian shelf conditions. During late Archaean and Palaeoproterozoic times, emerging cratons and supercontinents were subject to greater tectonic instability than generally prevalent in the Phanerozoic, and with the relatively poor chronological record available for this period, it will be difficult to differentiate between epeiric transgression due to eustatic and as a result of tectonic influences. It is, however, important that attempts be made to construct sea level curves for the Precambrian, based on world wide studies.
Glacigenic palaeoenvironments probably reflect the least significant differences between depositional systems from the Precambrian and Phanerozoicmodern periods. In contrast, the causes of pre-0.6 Ga glaciation point to a complex interplay of factors of distinctly Precambrian character, such as the emergence of cratonic areas above sea level, their amalgamation into the first supercontinents, an early CO2-rich atmosphere, the development of stromatolitic carbonates (e.g. Altermann and Nelson, 1998), early weathering processes, possible changes

in Earth’s obliquity (Williams, 1998), and faster rotation of the Earth.
Precambrian glacigenic events offer strong promise as an aid in Precambrian supercontinent reconstruction (Aspler and Chiarenzelli, 1998), in high-resolution chronostratigraphy and in helping to determine the sequence stratigraphy of such ancient successions (e.g. Pelechaty et al., 1996a,b). International cooperative programmes, concentrating on sequence stratigraphic studies and basin-wide analyses of depositional systems in the world’s Precambrian terranes, offer an important means for advancing our understanding of Precambrian geological history. Basin analysis techniques need to be applied to preserved Precambrian successions (e.g. Altermann and Nelson, 1998). Perhaps the next major effort should be directed towards elucidating Precambrian supercontinent amalgamations and breakups. This will not only enhance understanding of Precambrian climates, but will also contribute to understanding the temporal distribution of both aeolian and glacigenic deposits in the rock record. Thicker Precambrian delta deposits, indicating tectonically active settings and relatively deep receiving basins, contrast with the low-angle, wide shallow marine shelves where very large braidplain systems also debouched, to form large braid-delta complexes. The apparent differences in these two coastline situations warrant attention and may improve comprehension of Precambrian shelf dynamics.

abstractText: The unique and evolving nature of the Precambrian geological environment in many ways was responsible for significant differences between Precambrian clastic sedimentary deposits and their Phanerozoic-modern equivalents. Some form of plate tectonics, with rapid microplate collisions and concomitant volcanic activity, is inferred to have led to the formation of greenstone belts. Explosive volcanism promoted common gravity-flow deposits within terrestrial greenstone settings, with braided alluvial, wave=storm-related and tidal coastline sediments also being preserved. Late Archaean accretion of greenstone terranes led to emergence of proto-cratons, where cratonic and rift sedimentary assemblages developed, and these became widespread in the Proterozoic as cratonic plates stabilised. Carbonate deposition was restricted by the paucity of stable Archaean terranes. An Early Precambrian atmosphere characterised by greenhouse gases, including CO2, in conjunction with a faster rotation of the Earth and reduced albedo, provide a solution to the faint young Sun paradox. As emergent continental crust developed, volcanic additions of CO2 became balanced by withdrawal due to weathering and a developing Palaeoproterozoic microbial biomass. The reduction in CO2, and the photosynthetic production of O2, led to aerobic conditions probably being achieved by about 2 Ga. Oceanic growth was allied to atmospheric development, with approximately 90% of current ocean volume being reached by about 4 Ga. Warm Archaean and warm, moist Palaeoproterozoic palaeoclimates appear to have become more arid after about 2.3 Ga. The 2.4–2.3 Ga Huronian glaciation event was probably related to continental growth, supercontinent assembly and weathering-related CO2 reduction. Despite many analogous features among both Precambrian and younger sedimentary deposits, there appear to be major differences as well. Two pertinent examples are rare unequivocal aeolian deposits prior to about 1.8 Ga and an apparent scarcity of Precambrian foreshore deposits, particularly those related to barrier island systems. The significance of these differences is hard to evaluate, particularly with the reduced palaeoenvironmental resolution because of the absence of invertebrate and plant fossils within Precambrian successions. The latter factor also poses difficulties for the discrimination of Precambrian lacustrine and shallow marine deposits. Alternatively, the scarcity of aeolian deposits prior to 1.8 Ga may merely reflect non-recognition or non-preservation. Precambrian shallow marine environments may have been subjected to more uniform circulation systems than those interpreted from the Phanerozoic-modern rock record, and Precambrian shelves probably were broad with gentle seaward slopes, in contrast to the narrow, steep shelves mostly observed in present settings. Poorly confined Precambrian tidal channels formed sheet sandstones, easily confused with fluvial or offshore sand sheets. Epeiric seas were possibly more prevalent in the Precambrian, but active tectonism as proto-continents emerged and amalgamated to form early supercontinents, in conjunction with a lack of sufficient chronological data in the rock record, make it difficult to resolve the relative importance of eustatic and tectonic influences in forming epeiric embayments and seaways. Other differences in Precambrian palaeoenvironments are more easily reconstructed. Ancient delta plain channels were probably braided, and much thicker preserved delta successions in the Precambrian are compatible with the inferred more active tectonic conditions. Pre-vegetational alluvial channel systems were almost certainly braided as well. Common fluvial quartz arenites are ascribed to differences in weathering processes, which probably changed significantly through the Precambrian, or to sediment recycling. Although Precambrian glacigenic environments were probably the least different from younger equivalents, their genesis appears to reflect a complex interplay of factors unique to the Precambrian Earth. These include emergence and amalgamation of proto-continents, the early CO2-rich atmosphere, the development of stromatolitic carbonate platforms, early weathering, faster rotation of the Earth and the possible role of changes in the inclination of the Earth’s axis.  1998 Elsevier Science B.V.
